description:
The weather as of late calls for some pho! This is a nice gem of Nob Hill for Vietnamese food. It's a very casual environment. Nice, clean restaurant. We decided to try this place out since it was on the way home. I ordered the chicken pho (pho ga) which I thoroughly enjoyed. It was a perfect size and the broth was just right. My husband enjoyed his vegetarian pho & my son loved his shrimp veggie stir fry rice plate. We also ordered shrimp spring rolls, per usual. I will say the peanut sauce was super yummy but the spring rolls (you could tell) were not freshly rolled as the rice paper was a tad hardened.. but I really loved their pho ga. 

I ordered a Vietnamese iced coffee which was made perfectly strong (not mediocre-like strength as some other places). The staff was nice & welcoming as well. We didn't feel rushed out by any means like some other reviews have said and I thought the price was fair considering the area.
author: Ruby V.

description:
I had a hankering for some noodle soup today so I stopped into Pho Vietnam at lunch time. Rather than a traditional beef pho, I opted for a noodle soup dish with pork wontons, ground chicken and slices of pork. When the bowl came, I was pleasantly surprised that it came with the side dish of bean sprouts and basil branches. With the egg noodles used in this dish and a light chicken stock, I thought the noodle soup was meh.

I prefer rice noodles myself but didn't want to pay an extra $1 for this change. At $11.75 for this dish, it's pretty pricey. I'm sure there are better places for Vietnamese noodle soup but if you're in the area and need a pho or Vietnamese food fix, this is probably you're only option.

One thing though, this restaurant has a lot of choices for noodle soup; not just beef pho.

Service was very casual. The owners wave you to sit yourself at a table when you come into the restaurant, drop off the menus once you're seated and promptly give you the bill when you're close to finishing.

Lunch time today was pretty busy so there were a lot of workers who seem to be from the area and neighborhood locals getting a bite to eat.

In a pinch when I have a strong urge for Vietnamese food, I'd come back to Pho Vietnam. Otherwise, I probably would want to try somewhere else where the dishes have more flavor and are less expensive.
author: Joanna T.

description:
Pretty tasty, I come here on weekends sometimes and there's a normal flow of people that come in.

So far ive tried the bun bo hue and #23 both with broth and dry.

I liked it better dry because these clear noodles are easier to pick up when the broth doesn'tcoat it. I can also pick out certain ingrediemts easier since there's no broth to hide them. This dish has a lot of protein in it with the ground turkey and seafood. 

As for the bun bo hue, no surprises with this dish, your typical spicy soup dish.

There are a bunch of options and i intend on trying their raw beef dish because it looks so flavorful in the photo.

Restrooms are for customers only but they tend to get a lot of random walk ins from foot traffic on the strip.
author: Laura Y.

description:
A pretty decent pho place on Polk Street!

We ordered:
Imperial Rolls ($8.50) : Came with 6 small rolls but one of them was empty...lol I still ate it because the skin was still tasty 

My friend ordered a #9, which was "Thin slices of rare steak, well-done flank, tendon & tripe" ($11.75).

I had a #12, which was "Thin slices of rare steak and beef meatballs" with out onions or green onions, because they are the worst ($11.50).

Mine came with a tone of sliced meat but I was pretty disappointed with the meatballs. They were cut into quarters, instead of being actual balls...lol

I guess for pho, it ended up being a bit expensive, but it is on Polk Street. The service was fine and yes, I would go back here and also try their other dishes!
author: Alice L.

description: Pho Ga extra yummy, highly recommend this place if you're looking for something quick and fool proof.
author: Lourdes R.

description:
Food was quite disappointing. Won't be back - I'd rather walk a few more blocks than to waste stomach space and eat below average pho.

At around $11 for a bowl of pho, Pho Vietnam isn't exactly a cheap bowl of pho. I ordered the brisket and rare flank (asked for it on the side) pho and though the portion was sizeable, the flavor left something to be desired. The broth tasted very fatty but lacked both the beefy flavor and herbal notes I wanted from pho. They gave a lot of meat, but I prefer quality over quantity...

With a good bowl of pho, I never add any condiments (hoisin/sriracha/lime/jalapeno) into my broth because I want to conserve the original flavor. But here I found myself giving up on trying to find goodness in the broth and just dumped everything in. 

Oh AND I found a bug in my soup. I didn't even send it back because I can't say I was surprised it was there... Ah well, extra protein?
author: Sally L.

description: So I was in the mood and happened to be in SF. Craving a bowl of some good Pho. Guess what ? I found this little joint walking around and what a nice surprise. It's not a fancy place by no means which is good because typically you won't find good pho anywhere other than a mom and pop shop. This place is ran by a Vietnamese couple and it was very delicious ! We ordered the beef brisket , tendon with rice noodles and Vietnamese coffee. It was really good ! I was very surprised.  I got lucky this day because I was really craving Pho. We loved it.  By the time we left the placed was packed so that tells you a lot. Great find if your in SF
author: Andreas N.

description: Excellent pho. I usually get bo bun hue or wonton soup. The fresh rolls are also good. When I order this to go, there's easily enough to  split between two people. This is one of my go to spots for soup when I'm sick. Not much atmosphere here, but the food makes up for it.
author: Jennifer B.

description:
Not only am I Vietnamese, but I also grew up in east side San Jose where there is a ton of great Vietnamese food. My friends wanted to eat at this place and I was definitely hesitant at first because of the mixed reviews. 
My verdict? If you want good quality Vietnamese food then please go elsewhere.
This place was big enough to fit our group of 11 people, but they didn't seat us at tables next to each other or move tables together. One table got all their food and were practically done eating before the other table received their food.
I got Bun Bo Hue which lacked in flavor and the noodles were cut up into 2-3 inch length pieces...I definitely prefer my noodles being long and normal length. One friend got "Bo Luc Lac" (Shaking beef) and instead of being cube shaped it looked and tasted more like a beef stir fry.
Very disappointed with the food here, especially with the SF prices.
author: Yvi L.

description:
Delicious Vietnamese restaurant in the middle of Polk. Its layout is very similar to other Pho restaurants, with wide open space and tables with self serve utensils/napkins/condiments. 

Its an unpretentious place to get good food for a cheap price. My favorites are the Pho Dac Biet, the Chicken Pho, and the #34 Rice plate combo.
author: Justin I.

description: the highest price for a pho combination i eat in  California ever , it is 13.5$ with not too much meat , it will be around 9$ in othe pho shop.
author: Jason T.

description: Huge portions. No line ever. Hard to beat. This is a good neighborhood spot. Won't blow you away, but it's really convenient. The spring rolls and imperial rolls are good too. I'm surprised that they have this big place to themselves because I've never seen this place more than half full. The pho noodles and soup are standard and hit the spot. You have to go deeper in the tenderloin to find another pho spot, so this location definitely beats that.
author: Young Y.

description:
Rolls are good but soup, I ordered a Southern Vietnamese soup (Hu tieu nam Vang), isn't very a good tasty and too big. Much noodles and too much soup.
Correct but I cannot say more. I wait other advices but for eating Vietnamese dishes, I prefer going in another place.
author: Marie-Claire L.

description:
Good Mornin' Vietnaaaam!

Now that I got that of the way, let's talk about the food. My staple at Vietnamese establishments is the Bo Luc Lac. For those not familiar with this dish, it's basically beef cubes, veggies, and rice.

The beef cubes had a tasty flavor and were not over salted (problem at many places). However, they were not as tender as I would have liked and required a little more exercising of the masseter than anticipated. The rice and veggies were as expected.

At $13.50, this was a buck or two more than your standard price but given this is San Francisco, it's probably par for the course.

If you're looking for a decent spot that fills your Vietnamese cravings, this will likely do for most folks.
author: Mike O.

description:
I came here with friends for dinner and I was pleasantly surprised with how delicious and satisfying this pho is.  I ordered the pho ga and it was great. I added the dark sauce that they have on the table into my pho and it was very good-- wish I knew what the sauce was. 

The service is quick and the bowls are big! Loved it.  Perfect for a chilly SF evening! The decor isn't the best but it's somehow super relaxing because you can just chill, eat your pho and relax. Nothing fancy but very delicious.
author: Kelly F.

description:
I came here with intentions of getting my fresh spring roll cravings taken cared of.

the place is spacious, but also on a busy street, I parked around the block at the parking garage.

the place is decently big and good size tables.

I ordered Pork with fresh spring roll (Nem Nuong Cuon). I took a good 10 minutes.

2 rolls for about $9.

It was what I expected and good!
author: Roger A.

description: Very mediocre and a little over priced but i thought the pho was good. Egg rolls was not good.
author: Tina L.

description:
This is a small restaurant with some rather dated decor. It almost seems out of place as compared to some of the more modern shops that neighbor it on Polk.  

I tried the Pho Ga (chicken) and added mixed vegetables (broccoli, carrots, cabbage, etc). The broth was light but flavorful and didnt have that overbearing MSG/salty flavor that many American Vietnamese places are plagued by. 

My friend had the shrimp pho in vegetable broth and said that she enjoyed hers as well. I noticed that they were very generous with the shrimp, which is not typical. I look forward to coming back if I'm in the area.
author: Brittney B.

description:
FLY IN MY DRINK. 

There is nothing else I could start this review with other than the fact that there was a fly in my drink and the waitress barley batted an eye. About 120 seconds later, one of the people I was with pulled a HAIR out of her Pho. Just about 8 minutes later the woman sitting at the table next to us reported a fly in her SOUP. Nonetheless, it is safe to say this establishment should not have a health rating of A but a D. It was absolutely repulsive and the food itself was a C+ rating at best. If you are looking to eat here, find another place because it will be worn it. Absolutely horrible.
author: Collin V.

description:
Got the Pho Tai, Bo Vien. If you get the special, the bowl is actually larger. The regular size, as is, is already pretty big. The pricing is a little more than average, but the quantity justifies it. Never have I ever left a pho place before and felt full.

The broth is pretty decent and it comes out fast. You don't have to worry too much about a wait as people come and go.
author: James N.

description: the noodle was oke.... they gave me a lot of meats which is not always necessary... lot of green onions... the important is stil the noodle broth bottom line thats whats about pho... the only thing i dun really like is their beef balls... it tasted weird to me after seconds chewing it... but in the other hand, their coffee is real vietnamese coffee... ive been trying couple places for coffee, this coffee met my standards... bun bo hue is missing some ingredients, not like traditional viet style...
author: Michael P.

description:
+2 Stars for #1 fresh spring rolls

Tra thai should be made to order not ahead of time and sitting in refrigeration.

Quite disappointed with over priced #31 dry mealy clearly over cooked well ahead of my order shrimp.

Other order was #13 pho tai a staple with good broth and plenty of bef mystery meat in the soup.

Cmon people staple pho should be spot on every time.

Then my buddy gets an upset stomach from #13 Pho Tai.

Not going back.
author: Estiff S.

description:
I ordered the vegetarian pho (I think #47). It's a very big portion, but I found it to be pretty tasteless, actually. I was surprised and disappointed because a lot of other yelpers seemed to like it. I have had very flavorful vegetarian pho - both in Vietnam and elsewhere here - and sad to say that I felt this one was overpriced and disappointing.

But my friend likes some other stuff here, and I appreciate that they have some other veg options. So I might come back to try those. The place is clean, service is pretty fast, I just wasn't happy with my meal.
author: Annie J.

description:
I went yesterday because it was rainy and I wanted something warm. I walk pass this restaurant everyday on my way to work and have been wanting to stop by. 
The Pho was great and the service was on point. I will definitely stop by again in the future.
author: A C.

description: This place has my favorite Pho in the city. The quality of the meat and great taste of the broth are what really makes this place a stand out
author: Michael W.

description: seafood pho tasted weird, like it was spoiled. the lady serving us took 20 minutes to return our card because the machine didn't work and asked us for another form of payment.. and still waited really long to get our money back. terrible service.
author: Linore R.

description: LOVE, so delicious and fresh. Was really glad we found this gem. Customer service was good too. Definitely coming back.
author: Chrystal Anne M.

description:
Came by for a late lunch here yesterday afternoon. The space is pretty big, lots of tables, definitely room for some large parties. We were quickly seated and placed our orders.
I decided to go with the Pho Tai which is my go to. There is only one size here as oppose to other pho places where you can get a medium or large. The bowl was a good size and I was more than content with the portion. The meat was great! Quality was better than most of the other pho places around the city, and for the price I thought it was a great deal $9. My only complaint is the quality of the broth. I needed to add a good amount of Sriracha and lemon to get it to where I wanted which is never a good thing. Still pretty tasty nonetheless.
Overall I would definitely come back, the meat quality was awesome and the portions were great for the price.
author: Josue V.

description:
I've had a change of heart.  Pho Vietnam is one of my favorite spots in SF for a good bowl of soup...In fact, I come here about once a week!

My favorite thing to order is Bun bo hue (BBH).  While it's not like BBH An Nam in SJ, it's still very good!  However, the BBH doesn't have any pork...and one of my favs is cha lua!  Other than that, I find the broth to be delicious and very clean tasting.
author: Lisa Marie R.

description: This place is a staple in Nob Hill. They serve a great bowl of pho, or my personal favorite, hu tieu ca & ga. I love that their produce is clean and fresh.
author: Martha C.

description:
This is my favorite Pho place in San Francisco for a couple of reasons - It is only blocks from my house so yay for convience. The price is right, you aren't paying more than $11 for a massive bowl of steaming noodles and savoy broth. And the staff here is amazing. Seriously, every time I come here it is like a one man show. The lady will take your order, run to the back, make the food and bring it right back to you. All while running around, cashing out customers, greeting guests, clearing tables, refilling drinks, etc. It is great to watch these people are so hard working and although this is a no-frills Pho spot it hits the spot every time. 
One of the few places for Pho in town I have found that actually has vegan Pho. Most places have a 'vegetarian' option with beef broth (yuck). But this veggie Pho is packed full of broccoli, carrots, cabbage, tofu, noodles and has a clean simple taste, not super oily or greasy like I've found in a lot of noodle soups. Perfect to warm up with some fresh soup on a foggy San Francisco day.
author: Kelsey B.

description: Place is ok, but doesn't feel unhygienic, fortunately. I have only tried their varieties of Pho's and they are all good. Looking forward to try more of their dishes.
author: Roberto V.

description:
I have been here about several times over several years, but not much changes, they need a good cook.
I give 2 stars for the taste not improve .
author: Ngocart N.

description: I was happy to find very tasty vegan pho (pho chay) at this restaurant. The portion was nice and large and the service was good.
author: Carina B.

description:
I had a 3 star meal here and my boyfriend had a 1 star so I'm averaging between the two. 
DISCLAIMER: I don't eat red meat so this review is for other menu items besides pho. 

As others have noted, service is pretty minimal and the place is no-frills. Food comes out SUPER quickly once you order though. I had the pho ga (chicken rice noodle soup in chicken broth) and could see myself coming back to have it on a cold night. Very comfort-food ish, HUGE portion size, and I liked the chicken. I also enjoyed my thai iced tea. My boyfriend, however, ordered the co'm ga nuong nu (five spiced bbq chicken) and found it to be inedible. 

I think there are so many good vietnamese options on Polk & I don't think the quality of the food quite measures up.
author: Catherine S.

description:
This is a great pho spot! Good location on Polk Street and I found the service to be very nice and fast the couple times I've been here. There's plenty of seating inside and nothing fancy but always clean.

Got the pho combo with flank, brisket, steak, and beef ball, tendon, tripe ($10.50) and my boyfriend got the vermicelli pork bowl with imperial rolls ($10). Both were solid and had a really generous serving. The pork especially is so tender and perfectly flavored.

Highly recommend this place! Better than a lot of the pho restaurants I've tried in San Francisco.
author: Linda X.

description: Came here for the first time last week. I ordered the pho dac biet, and the bowl was HUGE. I wasn't super hungry to start, but I couldn't even eat half of it. Overall, it was a nice hot bowl with a heaping portion of meat and flavorful broth. It's walking distance from my new apartment, so I'm sure it will be a frequent stop for me.
author: Cynthia M.

description: Just had their pho about the third or fourth time and this will probably be my last. First off, it's a $14 bowl of pho. I got the #7. It's a ton of food and the broth is tasty too. But don't let that trick you, after about 5-10 min it starts tasting bad. Then I started tasting something weird with the meat. Really turned me off because I never had that taste from pho....ever. Service was nowhere to be found. I've been to Vietnam and I just can't understand why they mess up the pho so bad here.
author: Brian P.

description:
I love PHO and love trying all the places around my new work neighborhood. My friend turned me on to this place and we have now been here a couple times.

My favorite pho is the rare beef with this beef meatballs. I love adding lots of jalapenos, basil and sriracha hearts. Usually one bowl will leave me really full, but it's so delcious that I always attempt to eat it all. 

My friend will order different dishes including the chicken noodle and won ton soups. Everything looks pretty great, service is fast and the food is always affordable.
author: Rebekah T.

description: This place has great prices especially being in Nob Hill.  The food is quick and tasty.  The pho here is great for a hangover, cold day, and even post workout.
author: Crystal B.

description: Yikes, I must be spoiled by the Vietnamese food in the South Bay. I came here with a huge group while I was taking a class nearby. We each ordered our own bowls of pho/hu dieu, but everything tasted so bland. The broth didn't have any flavor, and the toppings weren't that great.
author: Angel K.

description:
The Cafe Sua Da (iced Vietnamese coffee with condensed milk) is a must order and great for the asian-kopi-missing souls. 
I had a piping bowl of Pho with beef slices and brisket which was tasty and pretty authentic. You could ask for fish sauce and lightly dip the beef slices in for an extra umami kick.
author: Yizhi A.

description: I've been coming here for years and unfortunately due to the city's ever growing prices, Pho Vietnam has had to follow suit. You pay quite a bit for a bowl of pho, but it is delicious! The brothis flavorful and unlike anything else in the city. But the quality of meat tops it off. I get the Pho Tai and it is always fresh, a great amount and perfectly sliced. Unfortunately, there is a lot of construction on the street right now so be prepared to drive around a few times for parking.
author: Crystal K.

description: Would highly recommend this place if you're looking for some high quality pho. I would advise eating at the restaurant versus picking up to go if you are getting any sort of soup dish. It's much better when they prepare it in house. Particularly love the spring rolls and any of their bowls
author: John R.

description:
Most dishes offered here are your typical pho noodle soups, vermicelli bowls, and rice plates... and taste good, but no different than most other places.  What sets Pho Vietnam apart are a couple vegetarian dishes that are quite tasty.

They offer a vegetarian rice vermicelli soup with a nice broth and chockfull of veggies.  They also offer a tasty vegetarian rice vermicelli plate loaded with shredded raw and cooked veggies and a deelish side sauce.  Either of these dishes hits the spot when you're looking for something on the lighter side.
author: Lee K.

description: This place provides mediocre Vietnamese food that I only go to because I'm too lazy or it's too late to trek through the tenderloin to get some food. It's totally decent food but one doesn't go out of their way to come here.
author: N A.

description: I've been to Pho Vietnam a handful of times and although the soup is nothing special, I've generally not had any huge complaints until recently. I came down with food poisoning from a bowl of Pho Tai and I'm going on 24 hours still with strong symptoms. I won't be going back.
author: Liam M.

description: Ordered cat fish claypot to go, very salty..!!! and took long time for wait, about 20 minutes. I never eat cat fish clay pot that salty !
author: Endah T.

description: My Vietnamese wife's and mine favorite bowl of Pho in San Francisco. Very traditional ingredients (multiple cuts of beef, tendons, tripe) and flavor (star anise, clove, pepper, etc.). Acceptable level of MSG. Incredibly large portion- one bowl is enough for two people.
author: Gene G.

description: EAT AT YOUR OWN RISK! I've come here several times by virtue of it being the only Vietnamese place by my apartment and while it's underwhelming, is sufficient. Food, service, cleanliness all meh, but recently, the pho led to the most violent case of food poisoning that I've ever experienced. Something was clearly mishandled or spoiled and despite my several attempts at calling to give them a heads up, radio silence. Won't be going back- permanently traumatized.
author: Mikachu K.

description: Had their chicken noodle soup last evening and it was DELICIOUS! Very tasty broth.
author: Diana B.

description: Delicious pho. Reasonable price. The staff is friendly enough. Inexpensive and again delicious.
author: Centeria S.

description:
I was leaving a friends house right next to Polk street so instead of hopping into my car and going home I decided to do my usual exploring the streets. 

It's nice to begin being familiar with the city and each district within it so I was surprised to see the diversity in food up and down Polk St. 

Of course I turn to Yelp restaurants browser to see what's good because I never know what I'm feeling until I see the type of cultural cuisines. 

My friend told me there were some Vietnamese spots around and I was kind of iffy about it because I felt it wasn't the real deal authentic Vietnamese food like I have back home :(.... 

Stumbled on Pho Vietnam with 4 stars and one dollar sign for Inexpensiveness!  That only means one thing! It's the real deal. I wanted to stay and eat pho but I also wanted to go home so instead I called to go for Bun Thit Nuong, Cha Gio! grilled pork with egg rolls over vermicelli. My usual to-go order.  

My walk over to the restaurant was 10 minutes away and the order would be done in 10 minutes so perfecto! Took it home and devoured it.

Good to know there's a inexpensive Vietnamese spot I can go to when I'm bored without my car in the city. 

Man I really want pho right now....
author: Jenny S.

description:
Omg omg omg. I am so happy I found this place a few months ago! I've dreamed of having an amazing pho place within walking distance of my apartment and my dreams have come true! I have to stop myself from coming here every day. 

Not only is this place super affordable the pho is to die for. I will say I have only tried the cha gio and the pho here only because the pho is so good that I never want to order anything else (same with the cha gio)! The reason is the broth. The broth is just YUM!! Not only is it super flavorful but the broth somehow magically stays the perfect hot temperature the whole time! Growing up, my sister and I were always taught that food has to be piping hot when served and to remain hot while you eat it. This both is exactly this!! Such a minor thing but huge in my book. 

I highly recommend getting the #7 pho dac biet. Not only does it have all the fixings including tendon and tripe (YAASSSS) but it is practically double in size compared to a regular bowl of pho for only a $1 more! Talk about a deal!

I love the Vietnamese ice coffee here as well. I love that it comes still dripping into the condensed milk and that you have to stir the coffee and condensed milk before pouring it over ice. Any food/drink that I can interact with is a win in my book.

This is my go to spot for when I'm craving some noodle soup. The hardest part is limiting myself and not going every day!!
author: Sabrina D.

description:
This is a great spot for tasty, quick, and inexpensive Vietnamese food!  This was one of my regular haunts when I lived in the neighborhood, and now that I'm out in the Mission, it's worthy of a visit when we're visiting the old 'hood.

The number 26 - grilled pork with vermicelli noodles and imperial rolls - is my favorite!  Flavorful, filling, and reasonably healthy.  My husband got the pho ga (chicken noodle soup) today and really enjoyed it.

The service is fast and friendly, and the restaurant is clean and simple.

Great food at a no-frills spot.
author: Barnali D.

description:
This is a great spot for some Authetic Pho. I'm usually very picky but their Beef Stew was amazing. It was really slow cooked and the broth was cooked to perfection. I thought my pho place by my house was already great, but this has topped the notch! I will be coming back when I'm in the SF area & craving some hot steaming pho! 

Btw, it's not the typical $7 pho. It's in the $9/$10 range but I guess for being in SF and a tourist area, it's pretty normal. And you can't pick the size of your soup, it's just one size/price for all. I was only able to finish half of my bowl! 

Anyways, see you soon Pho Vietnamese!
author: Jessica L.

description:
This is my spot to get a big bowl of Pho.  The prices are reasonable, and the Pho is solid.  I come here regularly (at times in big spurts) for the Pho and extra rare-beef slices.  They close by about 9:30 - but, still plenty of opportunity to watch the crowd on Polk Street pass by.  I also have had a few of their appetizers and they were good.

Overall, very quick service and good prices.  They are closed on Sunday (much to this guy's dining-chagrin).  I get the sense that this is a family business and that they take care to give a good meal and honest service to their customers.
author: Adam S.

description: Wow. I'm very impressed with their Bun Bo Hue. The broth is simply perfect! Super rich in flavors and just the right spiciness!
author: Amanda H.

description:
5 stars for takeout.  

The food is packaged nicely and when I've ordered pho, the broth is always hot.  #26 Grilled Pork Vermicelli, #1 Spring rolls and #17 Wonton Soup are my favorites.  I also enjoy the Pho Ga!

No frills for dining inside, yet the service has always been good.
author: Andrew H.

description:
Not knowing many places open late, I was looking for food around the area.  I was by myself and saw this one was open already.
I knew very little about Vietnamese food except their noodle soup with beef.  I am not a fan of any fried food.
The meat tasted good.  I don't eat a lot and I couldn't finish, the man server might be the owner was so nice to doggy bag the rest of the soup for me.
author: Anna P.

description:
Woh woh woh...fish and chicken noodle soup?! 

Yes, it exists. #21 at this unassuming restaurant nestled in the bustling Lower Polk neighborhood. The fish was actually quite tasty; a white fish that would commonly be found in Chinese porridge. It was tender and soft, and they were quite generous with the quantity as well. Not the most outrageous flavors I've ever tried, but definitely did the trick for the nasty cold I was going through.

Also, they were nice enough to provide hot water with lime! Helped my sore throat a bunch!
author: Audrey L.

description:
I don't know what these nay-sayers are talking about.  The staff, yea, they're not the nicest...but who cares!?  Consistent food.  Pho is bomb (great hangover cure, as others mentioned), imperial rolls are delicious, and when we order for takeout, they ALWAYS answer immediately and then say, "Ok, 10 minutes."  What more can you ask for in San Francisco? - the place where delicious food spots are overpriced, overcrowded, and never answer their phones for takeout orders...  

Whatever, people.  Keep rating this spot with 2's and 3's.  I'm happy keeping this place all to myself :)
author: Tiffany S.

description:
I've had ph at many places in San Francisco. My favorite choice -- though quite unauthentic -- used to be Zadin, which is now closed.

Regardless, Zadin was never near where I live. In my neighborhood, this place is my pick. I always order the #13 (rare, lean beef) and an iced Vietnamese coffee, reserving most of the condensed milk because I don't like it that sweet.

Now that it's open Sundays, I often go at about 11am and sit next to the big open window to stay cool while spicing up my soup.
author: David S.

description: Very disappointed! Chow main all you taste was garlic, it wasn't well fried. Their soup needed more flavor, there was no seasoning sauce on the table. Over the nasty food we had 2 children with us and she only gave us 2 glasses of water, after she clearly see our kids reaching over the table for our cups. The price was higher, for all the Asian looking for real authentic Vietnamese food, this is not the place!
author: M M.

description:
It took me like 5 tries to find a clean spoon. Ew.

Otherwise, the food is always consistent. Kind of spendy for a bowl of pho. ($11 including tax and tip for a #1)

It makes me wish I lived closer to Chinatown. ;(
author: Angela L.

description:
Well I'm no expert in Vietnamese food.  I just know what I like here and I keep coming back for #26 Bun Thit Nuong, Cha Gio (grilled pork, 2 imperial rolls, over vermicelli).  It just hits that happy spot for me.  Really love that slight char flavor on that pork....mmmm.  I give it 4 stars for this dish alone.

I can't comment on other dishes, but will say that the service seems a bit slow when I've eaten in.  I mean, if I'm one of the few customers there, I'd think it would be quicker service. The restaurant overall is fairly clean and has plenty of seating, but I've never seen a packed house. 

Also - just noticed a sign posted that starting on 6/22, they will open on Sundays!!
author: Alvin J.

description:
My friend took me here before a movie, and it was his treat, I didn't have a say in where we went. That said, I do love pho - but there wasn't much to choose from their menu for a vegetarian - and the orders came out not more than 2 MINUTES after we were served our appetizers, which was appealing to my friend, but strange in my view.
Can't say I'd return here. I prefer getting my pho in the richmond or inner sunset, anyway.
author: Kristina B.

description:
After a long ass night I was in desperate need of some good pho. I saw that this was only a 10 min walk from where I was staying at and they had a vegetarian menu so to Pho Vietnam i went! Spacious place with lots of tables and pleasantly very clean too! 

Unfortunately, I didn't bother to check out their veggie menu completely bc when I got there I saw that they did not have veggie pho. So instead, I ordered the Banh canh tom cua which is basically a spicy version of seafood soup. It had mainly crab (a big ass crab claw as well) and shrimp and yummy thick noodles.

Portions are good..I was only able to finish half of it but I had also ordered one shrimp roll which tasted pretty standard. I mean....you would have to really try to mess up a shrimp roll, right? Their thai tea is not sweet at all which was perfect to my taste. 

Oh, ask for cilantro..it doesn't come with the soup :]
author: Jenn K.

description:
I'd walk a mile for a good bowl of pho, but even more adventurously, I'd take my life in my hands and take the 19 through the 'Loin if that was the goal. In this case, Jamie W. and I just took the California Street cable car over Nob Hill and jumped off at Polk to get here. Thank goodness, as the pho at Pho Vietnam is merely decent. What makes the difference between great and middling pho is the broth. Turtle Tower, at least the original one on Larkin, does it right, while others not so much. I'd put this pho in the middle of the pack. Good enough to slurp but not enough to remember for a return visit.

Part of the problem is that the waitress refuses to crack a smile here. Not sure why the frown, but it made us feel like we were being sent to our room for our supper. Things started on a promising note with the $3 half order of the Vietnamese Spring Rolls (Goi Cuon) which were crispy-fresh with the standard combo of shrimp, lettuce and vermicelli noodles accompanied by a thick, dark peanut sauce (see photo). What was weird was that I thought I ordered the full portion for the both of us to share, but we let is pass since more food was coming. Jamie felt he took a wrong turn with an order of the $8.75 Grilled Pork with Imperial Rolls (Com Thit Nuong, 3 Cha Gio), which turned out to be blandly generic in flavor and execution (see photo).

He also went for the small $3.50 bowl of Beef Ball Soup (Chen Bo Vien) but couldn't quite get over the rubbery texture of the balls for reasons that were all too clear (see photo). So I was the one that went for the pho, the big $8.25 bowl of Pho Dac Biet with all the meat fit to eat - the rare steak, the well done flank, the brisket, the tendon, the tripe and the beef balls (yes, me too...) And of course, it came with the thin vermicelli noodles, the snap-ready bean sprouts, the basil, the lemon wedges, and the pepper slices (see photo). Everything was there that you would expect from a combo bowl of pho, but the beef broth was just too diluted to lend any flavor impact. That was the most disappointing aspect to my dish, and uncharacteristically, I left most of the broth in my bowl. Oh well, it was worth a shot. And please smile, will ya?

FOOD - 3 stars...middling Vietnamese fare would put it somewhere near the DMZ, wouldn't it?
AMBIANCE - 3 stars...large, sunny space but...
SERVICE - 2 stars...unhappy, unsunny people serve here
TOTAL - 3 stars...I'd walk a mile for good pho, so I better keep walking to Little Saigon
author: Ed U.

description:
No frill Pho place near my place. 
Good portion, soup base and clean dining room.
author: Albert C.

description:
Good prices, quick service, and tasty Vietnamese food, you won't be disappointed here. We ordered the chicken pho and vegetarian spring rolls when we came in for lunch and it was exactly what we wanted and needed. The fresh spring rolls come with peanut sauce (yum!) and the pho is served with a plate of sprouts, jalapenos and basil to add in to your taste. 

Only drawback, there isn't a lot of vegetarian options on the menu. It won't dissuade me from returning as the rolls are quite delicious.
author: Cassandra J.

description:
Short Story:
An average Pho place in SF.

Long Story:
I came here on a Wednesday night with a few friends in search of a late night dinner.  I got there around 9:30PM and was promptly seated.  I ordered the Pho with been and meatballs.  As usual, the waiter quickly took our order and the food came out in a short time.  The food was alright.  Standard and what you would expect from a pho place.  The decor and ambiance were standard too...nothing to praise, but nothing to complain either.

Verdict:
I'll go back if I'm in the area and in want of pho.
author: Michael W.

description:
Had dinner here tonight with friends. Very good food. Not over the top customer service but the servers recommendations were on point. 
Only complaint is there's really nothing special about it, nothing about he decor or menu is over the top unique or interesting. 
The food was really good and came with all the extras. I got the chicken pho which was super yummy and was a very large portion. 
Get the coconut! The coconut water and fresh coconut were so awesome. Definitely hit the healthy desert spot. 
And to top it all off, 4 people with drinks was only $55 and we all walked away full and satisfied. 
Definitely recommend this place. Will be coming back.
author: Lacey K.

description: We came here from out of town and love the Pho soup...friendly staff.
author: Cindy M.

description:
I was here and had the Five-spiced Chicken and I have to say it was not very good.  The chicken lacked flavor and the texture was a bit off...considering it's "five-spice", I was surprised by how plain this dish was. The spring rolls were okay...

Maybe Pho is the thing to order here, but I would not recommend the chicken dish I had.
author: Ken G.

description: Yummy- good for vegetarians if you get double noodle double veggie. Casual dining, quick service
author: Sarah M.

description:
Had a grilled pork vermicelli with spring rolls and a beef pho 
Vermicelli was "meh" and spring rolls weren't tasty... The grilled pork was great though, although slightly charcoaled.
Beef pho was nothing special and tripe wasn't the best quality... Hard to chew and overcooked. Rest of the soup base and noodles were just like any other Vietnamese place.
Clean and tidy for food. Maybe a visit if I'm feeling too lazy to walk into Chinatown.
author: Jennifer W.

description:
Very good and authentic Viet cuisine
Will be back 
You CAN Tell The Quality of The place by The freshness of vegetables .
author: Bob D.

description: If you like Vietnamese pho, this place is NOT the place to go! The soup is really bland, I honestly thought I was drinking hot boiled water.. -_- but two stars for giving me a LOT of meat! The noodles are too soggy, and it almost felt like I was eating jook (porridge)! I couldn't finish eating my bowl of pho like I usually do but it wasn't even a little satisfying for me to finish it! My girlfriend ordered the chicken pho but it definitely wasn't the real deal. Their chicken soup was definitely just water and some msg! No skin were on the chicken and the chicken they used were chicken breast that you can get from Safeway, Costco, etc. I usually don't give less than 3 stars but this place, I will never come back even if it were the only place open for pho! I am a pho lover and if a pho restaurant cannot satisfy my pho needs, then it's definitely a no go! Service is mediocre but it's a pho restaurant, what do you expect people! You eat your food, then pay and then leave! Anyways, I hope this place does good later on in the future, I would never wish end on anyone's business because their food sucked!
author: Isaac K.

description:
Can't say I was super impressed by this spot.

I was trying to be kind to my stomach as I had food poisoning yesterday and thought Pho would be a good option for lunch. Maybe it was just the veggie pho, but it was so unflavorful!!! 

I had to douse the bowl with soy sauce. It almost tasted like they just heated up water and put all the noodles and veggies in there because there was literally no flavor!! 

The menu was pretty impressive and I can imagine the beef and chicken Pho having more flavor. Based on what I had, I wouldn't rush back any time soon. Three stars for the fresh coconut water served out of a coconut.
author: Christine E.

description: Definitely not the best Pho that I have ever had. Pretty salty, but still a decent option. If you go, get the pho and not one of the other dishes on the menu. Good hangover cure, but definitely not a place I will be returning to often
author: Ross S.

description: Best pho in the vicinity. Lots of goodies in soup and not skimpy quantity at good prices. Fresh Spring rolls are great too
author: Linn K.

description: 4 and a half stars, really. Very decent pho, which we appreciate even more now that we live an hour north of SF. Good broth. Maybe a little less tripe than I could wish for--there's no tripe-heavy combo, so I did my best. Fast, friendly service. Someone commented on the trimmings--actually they were fresh and delicious, no different than a million places in the area but very nice all the same (basil, sprouts, chili, yada yada). I couldn't finish the vat of pho (I ordered #7, all the fixins') and the server informed me she added extra broth to my take-out container. The restaurant was tidy and bright. I saw people ordering other things that looked wonderful. Rock on, Pho Vietnam.
author: Karen S.

description: If you're a pho lover person, this is NOT the place for you. Their pho tasted so freaking bland! So disappointing!
author: Sandy K.

description: Average place. Friendly worker. The food was O.K.  I suppose because it's SF so the prices are a bit higher. But I didn't expect the ice tea to be $1.90 each. So keep that in mind if you are going to ask for ice tea.
author: Haley W.

description: I used to live in the area and love this place that even I move to Soma. I still come here once for a while to enjoy the food. The soup noodles here is just so so. Too much msg. But he grilled dishes: grill pork ,five spiced chicken etc are super tasty and good. Please come and make sure your try any of their BBQ dishes :) Bon appetit!
author: Tia C.

description: I have to say I was pleasantly shocked upon tasting this restaurants food.  The service wasn't so friendly and the space was dead inside but the Pho was Pho-nomenal!  Basil and bean sprouts are served on the side with a pho-BBQ sauce and spices waiting on the table ready-to-go.  Add as much or as little as you want to the dish of your choice to make it a bit more tasty to your buds needs.
author: Kevin J.

description: Wonderful food and great people. I'm visiting town from Austin and I found Pho Vietnam here on Yelp. I'm so glad I came here. This was the best Pho I've ever had. So fresh and amazing. The restaurant is clean and bright but I took mine to go. I ordered Pho Ga (pho with chicken) and veggie spring rolls. They gave me shrimp spring rolls instead and I'm allergic, so I called to let them know. I came back the next day and they gave me a free order of veggie spring rolls. They were so good. I'd come back here anytime.
author: Amy S.

description:
Going gaga.

Not really for me: https://www.youtube.com/user/LadyGagaVEVO

Absolutely for me: Catfish and chicken rice noodle soup (Hu Tieu Ca & Ga). Former was steamed. Latter white meat only. Clear broth with minimal oil. Just $9.

Excellent in taste, health and price. Staff is friendly and approachable while the space is unassuming. No doubt there are plenty of other menu items that are just as good.

Zero pretension. Full gaga.
author: Jason B.

description: Nice quiet ma/pa op. Pho is good, broth is slow cooked. Good balance of meat and noodles. Sauce isn't watered down. Didn't think there was decent pho in the city.
author: Starry H.

description:
I'm so glad this place exists! It's one of the only places to get pho without venturing into the Tenderloin. It's also nice that they have plenty of seating, so you never have to worry about a long wait. 

The pho is tasty, less than $10, and they are very generous with their portion sizes - lots of noodles, broth, and meat! 

I've been here several times and have also gotten it to go. They do SUCH a great job packaging to go orders. They package the noodles and meat separate from the broth and veggies (bean sprouts, basil, jalapeno) so you can put it all together when you're ready. They're very, very considerate and have prompt service.
author: Tiffany Y.

description:
Imho, this place is underrated. I've come here about once a week for 2.5 months and the ingredients are consistently fresh and delicious.

Get the #17 soup. It's the best (egg noodles, ground chicken, sliced pork, pork wantons).
author: Nikolay V.

description: Meh, not so spectacular. Standard canned soup base with some bean sprouts and basil. Uninspired food staff that don't look happy and bring that to your table. Is there a better place close by?
author: Matt A.

description: Pho is really good here! I like the taste, spring rolls were delicious. My friend ordered minced lime chicken, the taste and flavors were very good! But the chicken was over cooked and dry. Everything else was perfect! I would recommend to anyone.
author: Margarita V.

description: Ordered food here once when I was hung over for pick up and it was ready in 15 minutes. Good start. I called in an order today for pick up in 15 minutes. I showed up as my fiancé double parked, expecting to grab food. 25 minutes later I am still here, waiting for my order. And they keep saying it's coming. There are four other people in here. They keep ignoring me as if I'm not here without any explanation. Never coming here again.
author: Jeff W.

description: Ordered chicken pho, was advised they had no chicken broth, so I asked for beef. A bowl of chicken pho in beef broth showed up. It was okay. The imperial rolls were okay as well.
author: Maximillian M.

description:
My first pho! I've always wanted to try pho, and I had heard San Francisco Vietnamese is unrivalled. I was not disappointed. Not only was this restaurant very convenient (right behind my hotel, holiday inn golden gate), but the servers were very friendly and accommodating, the restaurant was clean, and of course, most importantly, the food was delicious. 
I got the #10, beef brisket with rare beef pho. In addition to the meat, it had noodles and scallions in the broth, and came with a plate of sprouts, lime, chilis, and basil for my date and I to share as garnishes. All the necessary spoons, chopsticks, sauces, and bowls were provided on the table. I thoroughly enjoyed my meal, and felt it was an excellent deal for the price (between $8 and $11), especially considering the large portions. What a great first experience! :-)
author: Paula R.

description: Possibly the worst service I have ever seen in SF! The lady had an attitude to everyone. She also had her favorite table that she gave all her time to and everyone else saw it. There are way to many places in the city to ever have to choose this place. I believe this is my first 1 star rating ever on Yelp. Btw, we have been here for 15 minutes and still not a water yet but yet the table after us has received all their drinks and food. I will be posting this on all my social media sites also. I hope management sees this message. Btw, I didn't know that dogs were allowed in restaurants that cooked food in the city unless it was on a porch? Health inspectors please take note on this.
author: Drew P.

description: I love this place. Have been coming here for 10 years. Best pho in the area. I always get the pho tai. The broth and stock is essential to good pho and these guys get it right. When the broth is that good you want lots of noodles to slurp up.  They get that right too. Loads of noodles and great thinly sliced rare beef.
author: Roddy M.

description: I love this place. Solid location for some good pho on a cold day. This place is no frills, sit down and eat type vibe. That broth is so damn good. Mmh
author: Michelle A.

description:
A great place for Pho on a rainy night in SF! I got the beef brisket Pho (#10 on the menu) as well as the shrimp spring rolls. Both came out in a timely manner and were delicious. Atmosphere is nice too - grab a window table and people watch Polk Street.

I was also really pleased with how clean the restaurant is. The tables and floors were all pretty spotless. 

Definitely going back soon!
author: Shelby R.

description:
I personally think this place is a solid pho joint that's close to my house and will be saving me on many Sunday mornings.. service was good - the owner of the restaurants were prompt, patient, and nice, which is somewhat of a novelty in SF pho places.

My boyfriend fell in love with this place because they make a great pho bo kho, a spicy Vietnamese beef stew. The broth is much thicker than that of which you encounter in regular pho, and a lot more flavorful. Most restaurants don't make this dish, as it's usually homemade, but they knocked it out of the ball park here and they get 4 stars for me!
author: Chrystal Z.

description:
A quick walk from my hotel while in town for a long weekend, this Pho place was a great find. We had terrible expensive Italian (a stretch to even call it that) from across the street the night before, so I was looking for some soup on the cheap to soothe my itchy throat around 9pm. Saw Pho Vietnam from my room and headed down for a (hopefully) better experience.

I shared a big bowl of Pho Ga (Chicken) with mom, some spring rolls and fried bananas with ice cream. The broth was flavorful and yum with crispy fried onions that adds just a little bit of flavor. Like Spaghetti, every pho broth is different - but this was yummy and had plenty to share. Spring rolls were fine and bananas were actually little triangles of egg roll crispy crust and mashed banana inside. The total bill was $20 and I left feeling satisfied and not ripped off.

**Note: Mom said on the way from the bathroom they were actually on their hands and knees scrubbing the floor of the kitchen, so cleanliness is not a problem here.
author: Paxy D.

description: Ate #22 beef stew carrots pho. Tasty entree. Service a little slow with two tables eating. Parking on the Polk street meters, not enforced after 6pm, but tough finding a space. Many other restaurants in area worth checking out.
author: Clifford W.

description: This place is pretty solid and it hits the spot when I'm craving some tasty, piping hot pho! It's very affordable, clean, and the service is quick. I ordered out from them once and they packaged everything very well...it kinda felt like I was eating it in-house! So if you're looking for a hidden pho gem you should check out this place.
author: Dana B.

description: This place was pretty good! The food came out very quickly. I have been craving pho for weeks now and it was as good as any other pho I've had. The staff is also very friendly. As a Midwesterner, I was baffled by the coffee press they handed me, so the owner took over... I will definitely return when I get another pho craving.
author: Kelsey S.

description:
Food here is as good as other pho places in Nor Cal.  They also give you ample portions and plenty of beef in your soup noodles. 

However, the soup here is heavily msg-ed.  Expect to be thirsty after.  

And the service here is not bad - quick and efficient, yet attentive.  

But man - that's a lot of msg.
author: Mark M.

description:
I came here tons of times then I know why is did stop coming here. After walking around and starving I decided to give this place another try. I used to like this place and was a regular then the service was going down the hill, the food was getting bad and they raised the price a bit.
Not to mention the tables are all sticky, wet or oily. Seems like they no longer care using a clean tag to wipe the tables.

Anyway I am not sure if I will be back maybe if I am desperate enough then I will give this place another try.
author: Ty N.

description: It was JUST ok. Food had no flavor at all. I got #27 and it was really bland. I wouldn't come back here.
author: Jenny M.

description:
It's okay. I came with a large group of friends worn out from partying at Lush across the street. We grabbed a handful of tables and really wanted our pho!

They were very confused when bringing our orders back. The waiters didn't know who ordered what, and given that they only told us the numbers, we were very confused too.

The noodles here were kind of a in a solid lump and difficult to get at. Broth was decent, meat was decent. We got some tea as well, but we had to remind them multiple times for the coconut we ordered.
author: Michael W.

description: Delicious, large portions, varied toppings, adaptable with requests, AND affordable. A winning combo!
author: Nicole N.

description: The quality of the food was okay, but the prices were a little more expensive than what I'm used to -- ~$10 for a regular bowl of pho tai with added veggies.  The service was also quite slow -- which is odd for a pho restaurant, and considering there was only one other customer in the restaurant.  Probably not coming back.
author: Anna C.

description: One of my favourite Vietnamese restaurants here in Nob Hill, SF. Nothing fancy, Mom & Pop style restaurant with good eats!
author: hans simon f.

description: Absolutely my worst meal ever in SF. I'm a personal Chef specializing in Japanese and Italian cuisine and this meal was quite disappointing. The Beef Pho had processed roast beef in it. Absolutely atrocious. With all the great Ramen in this town, I'm shocked this place is still open. Mere Chicken broth out of a can and noodles compares. The Com Xao Thap Cam was nearly barely edible. Every piece of protein (beef, chicken, shrimp, calamari) was tough, dry and tasteless, as if it was prepped in the morning or the day before. This dish besides the noodles and vegetables was not prepared in the timeframe my order was taken. Most of what was ordered was left on the table.
author: M m.

description: Pho Vietnam accomplishes exactly what it sets out to achieve. It is a no-frills restaurant with plenty of space, attentive service, and dishes that taste exactly like you would want and expect.
author: Kate T.

description: It's my Go-To Place when I'm in the neighborhood. I got the Bun Thit Nuong... Your basic Viet dish... It's a staple and they make it fairly well. Beware the random chewy/grisly pieces of pork... There is always one or two pieces but still good all the same. I've had a lot of their items and their cuisine is basic Viet home cooking... No frills. Just good 'ole basic Viet good... Reminds me of my mom and ba noi (grandmothers) cooking.
author: William N.

description:
I come here frequently for lunch and its pretty decent pho. However, today I tried the beef carpaccio and it tipped the scale in favor of the restaurant! It was the first time I've ever had beef carpaccio but i feel like it was pretty good! 

Good. Cheap. Pho. *thumbs up*
author: Jean T.

description:
Looking for a Pho place to call my own I found Pho Vietnam. Like many other Pho restaruants they have the open cafeteria decor with the oddly placed poster pictures adorning the walls...but the Pho is great and this is all that counts.

As soon as you order the Pho it arrives faster than you can say "Pho Vietnam"- the portions are huge and the broth is delicious. I have tried a lot of the fun things on the menu including the Fresh Shrimp rolls and the #10 (these are my favorites).  Don't forget the fresh lemon aid or a Thai tea.

Staff isn't into conversation- but you will have a pleasant experience.
author: Sarah M.

description:
Hu tieu nam vang was sort of whatever. The broth was really just a little too salty without enough of it's own flavor coming through.

I do see that they have bun cha hanoi so I will probably be back at some point to try it.
author: Misha T.

description: I like this place for decent Vietnamese food like vermicelli with bbq pork and imperial rolls or pho ga (chicken noodle soup).  The pho ga is a little on the salty side, but for the prices and quick service, it's tolerable.
author: Maile N.

description: Food & service were okay but nothing I'd go running back for. The spring rolls with peanut sauce were decent, though the shrimp seemed kind of rubbery to me. Ingredients seemed fresh & presentation was attractive. Two of us got grilled prawns served over vermicelli noodles. Good flavor, good quantity of prawns. Not very exciting, though. My gf got the veggie chow mein--she really liked it. Vietnamese iced coffee was quite good (I only had a taste)--very tasty, strong; interesting presentation. Water glasses were very small and weren't refilled.
author: J R.

description: I like this simple place for Pho. The steak is really tender and you get a lot of it. The broth is aromatic and tasty and the sprouts and basil are fresh. The ice coffee is so good. I took the rest to go for later.
author: Tina B.

description: Pho after a night of drinking. I got what I usually get at Pho places, which is the combination Pho with everything. My bowl was pretty big, however there wasn't too much of the meats. It was mostly noodles. The broth was clear and flavorful which was nice because I don't like those super dark Pho broths. Overall, decent place to get cheap Pho. Service is quick as well.
author: Juan F.

description: Since the last review, everything seems to have improved. No sticky table this time, no fruit fly in my water, and yummy pho. Definitely coming back more often.
author: Missy X.

description:
This is an odd place. It feels like you're in some run down tenderloin-ish joint by the way this place is decorated and the old ladies here treat you like dirt from the moment you walk in. You can't get a word in to ask a question about something on the menu before the old woman is already walking away making you wonder if she heard you at all.

I came in on a cold, windy SF summer day craving pho and willing to give this place a try since it's got 3.5 Yelp stars after all. I sat down, pointed to the seafood pho and asked for rice noodles as she walked away from me. Seriously, who walks away from a table while they're still talking?? I let it go 'cause I figured she probably heard me and was one those awesome servers who just knew exactly what you wanted and surprised you. Nope, not this lady.

A bowl of fishcakes with 2 tiny shrimps and 2 pieces of squid were presented to me with the tiniest amount of brown noodles. Brown noodles? In pho? When I asked for rice noodles? Those should all be strikes against this place. To top it off, the bean sprouts on the table were clearly the quality of the ones you find in the bottom of the bin. You know what I mean-the broken 1/2 inch twitchy ones with the roots still attached. For some reason, I instinctively took the roots in my hand and started snapping them off like I was in the kitchen of a Korean restaurant making appetizers again. 

Overall, this place blows. The noodle portion is sad, the bean sprouts looked like they were collected from the garbage in Chinatown, there was no lime or lemon to be seen anywhere in the restaurant and the broth was like hot water mixed with Dashi. Avoid this place and do yourself a favor and walk down to the 'loin for good pho at Turtle Tower.
author: Jessica K.

description: the restaurant was clean and the food came out fast but the pho noodles were really over cooked. the fried bananas were really tasty
author: Alice T.

description:
After a couple of hours of drinking, we desperately needed pho within the vicinity of Polk Street. Alas, we stumbled upon this pho restaurant. Off the bat, you can tell it is a bit more pricey than other pho restaurants. $9.95 for a Special (#1). Wowsers! 
 
Nonetheless, I came here with no expectation. I ordered the Bun Bo Hue. Surprisingly, the broth came out decent with the lemon grass flavor. All that was missing was that spicy kick that makes Bun Bo Hue infamous. Nothing a little Sriracha cant fix at the moment. They have only the steak meat, no pigs blood or pigs feet, catering to a more Americanized crowd.  
  
Service was decent, they came over when you wave them down. 
 
I would not mind coming back here again after a night of drinks.
author: Becky Q.

description:
This is one of my favorite vietnamese places to stop on my way home and grab some good food at a good price. I get either the #25 or 26 consistently.  

It's a little family-run place that is totally unpretentious, simple and serves decent food for a reasonable price. You can have an entire meal here for $10 per person. Seriously. 

The owners are almost always serving and maybe even cooking (I'm not sure). We've chatted a bit on occasion. They're friendly, but don't offer the fawning, ear-to-ear grin and tableside entertainment that so many of us spoiled Americans consider good service. The decor is basic but clean, cafeteria, pho-house style. The food arrives quickly, my water is always full and I have never once felt hovered over nor neglected. The service is just right. :) 

What more can you expect at a pho joint? It is what it is and is not trying to be a fancy restaurant. For what it is, it's pretty good! 

Oh, and the posted health department score is a 98.
author: N B.

description:
Vietnamese people: yall got some bomb ass food. 

I was hanging out yesterday and enjoying my sunday by reading the paper and such. I got hungry and went down the street to Pho Vietnam.

The area isn't spectacular (polk gulch) but my meal was. I ordered the Bun thit nuong. It was pork on vermicelli and it was delicious. It was also only $6.50 which is always fine by me. 

The place is not romantic in any way, but it is a large space.

The staff were quiet (I'm guessing not much englsh) but they refilled my water immediately several times and the food was brought out quickly.
author: Carlos A.

description: Best Pho place in the Polk Street area! Very friendly family and delicious huge bowls of pho. Definitely drop by here and enjoy a dinner for less than $10!
author: Matthew M.

description: The slowest service ever.  And I'm speaking in asian standards.  2 bowls of pho tai, waiting 25 minutes and counting.  I'll stick to socal pho where it's out in 2 minutes
author: Scott M.

description:
Came here with a friend for lunch today and things started off fine. We were quickly acknowledged and our server [possible owner/higher up] helped me to locate all of the vegetarian options scattered about their menu. After clarifying that the broth is indeed vegetable based, I sign up for a nice bowl of veggie noodle soup & my girlfriend gets the chicken noodle.

Out they come & delicious they look! However, after scarfing down nearly half of my bowl, I find none other than a PIECE OF CHICKEN floating around in it. And it looks just like the hunks/shreds from my friend's soup. 

*GAH!* Why does this always seem to happen to me?!?

I pick it out and put it on the plate and wait for our server to come back. Once I finally get her attention and show her the culprit, she asks me if I'm vegetarian... [Umm, we went over this quite well when we first met, I thought?] So I say yes, to which she clarifies, "So no meat at all?" I reply, "Yes, for 10 years." It is at this point that our brief staring contest begins. She is just silent. No apology, no offering to get me a new bowl of soup, nothing. She just stood there. To break the awkward moment I slide my bowl toward her edge of the table and politely say, "Okay... Well, I'm done with this now." And she just walks away and leaves my bowl. Only to return several minutes later with our check--that also did not show any sign of courtesy by perhaps having a discount on my meal that I didn't even get to fully enjoy. 

So I left feeling robbed. $10 [yes, I still tipped her] for a half-eaten bowl of vegetable soup and the hopes of not getting stomach pains later from meat contamination. 

But what really sucks--for them and for me--is that I knew I wanted come back to try their curry once I saw how beautiful our soups were. However, I don't want to end up with that lady as my server again because I would just feel totally awkward.

+3 stars because I'm nice and my friend's soup was great, but -2 because there was a blatant lack of customer service.
author: Sarah S.

description: I am pretty picky when it comes to Vietnamese food. This place is absolutely awesome. I ordered pho tai, chin, and it was super tasty. I also ordered the fresh coconut and che ba mao, which is 3 color vietnamese bean dessert-yellow mung bean is my FAVORITE and they filled the cup halfway with this yellow bean-so sweet and yummy. I would definitely recommend this pho restaurant to anyone craving vietnamese food! I will definitely be coming back and I am happy to call this my neighborhood pho restaurant!
author: CHristine J.

description: I came here on a weekday around 3PM and the Pho was horrible!! Broth was old and had no taste while rice noodles were murky to say the least. It was as if all the ingredients and Pho had been re-heated up and brought out after my order. I ordered extra beef and the soup was not warm enough so the beef was pink throughout my experience. WILL NEVER GO BACK here
author: Yelper H.

description: Medium. Not bad. Not amazing. My favorite part was that they had hot sauces on the table.
author: Jasmine S.

description:
Caveat: I have ONLY ever had pho here so I have no idea if the other items are good or not.
Having said that, I LOVE the pho at Pho Vietnam.  Being a pho fan (I always get pho tai). I have been to several places in the city in an attempt to branch out from Pho Vietnam and I never like them as much (and I especially don't get the hype about Turtle Tower). 
Lastly, the owners are always the only two people working in the front of the house and are fast and friendly. I come here often and they ALWAYS know my order as soon as I walk in and bring me all the specific extras I want without having to ask.
author: Kristina W.

description:
The best thing about Pho is eating a big bowl of it on a cold, windy, rainy night in the city. 5 min walk from my place? Even better. I ordered the veggie Pho, while my bf ordered the rare slices of beef Pho. He was sick at the time, and it helped warm him up and make him feel better, aww. Mine didn't have as much flavor, b/c like I said it was the veggie version so it didn't have meat juice dripping in it...but it was still soothing and yummy. 
I wouldn't say it's the best Pho I've ever had, but it's good enough to go back. However, it was weird how everyone got served way before we did...ppl that came in after us and ordered after us. Maybe they didn't like us or something haha.
author: Sonya D.

description:
I ordered and noshed on the #12 (Pho Tai, Bo Vien in case you're wondering) which is the pho noodle soup containing thin slices of rare steak and beef balls. The noodles were clumpy, and the beef slices were thin and non-plentiful in my bowl. The beef balls consisted of two balls that were cut in quad-pieces (ie, eight quad-pieces). The soup was just okay.

I would have gone to Turtle Tower or Pho 2000 except it was pouring rain that afternoon and this place was about two blocks from an account of mine. 

I chose convenience over a known-commodity. When will I learn?
author: Derek N.

description:
Not a bad place at all. Super surprised by the quality and authenticity of the soup considering it was in Polk. Will definitely b coming back! So excited to find this places I would recommend the pho tai Bo vein.

tip: if u can tho, i would advise u to venture a few bblocks down to pho 2000 which has more authentic pho, but be ready for a bit of a scary walk...
author: Thach N.

description:
Don't come here expecting awesome customer service. Their lack in customer service is made up with how fast your meal comes out.

I had the pho with white meat chicken and it was alright. Just alright. The chicken wasn't that great and was very.. chewy. I wish they had onions in their pho, and cut their broccoli to be a little more bite size and not give the ends of cabbage. Noodles were good though and the broth was hot.

Next time I'll just venture into the tenderloins and go to one of the many pho spots.
author: Sarah H.

description:
Solid pho but I really come here for their beef carpaccio (~$7.50), which is drenched in lemon juice and fish sauce topped with curly fried onions, chopped up bits of peanuts, scallions and mint. I wrap up the beef with all the toppings and let the juices fall in my mouth. Best Vietnamese beef carpaccio I can find so far. I don't prefer the ones with shredded carrots as it takes away the flavor. They used to give more beef. Now the plate looks more bare. 

Their imperial rolls are smaller than most Vietnamese restaurants and it is jam-packed with garlic flavor. The meat is too mushy, like you can't tell if it's really meat anymore because it has been frozen for too long. The combination appetizer (~$7.95) is a good option if you want to try their fish cakes, imperial rolls, and spring rolls. Comes with peanut (?) sauce and fish sauce. 

In terms of soup, my fiance really enjoys their spicy noodle soup. 

Prices are a bit higher than the TL pho joints, but everything is more expensive these days. What happened to the days of $4-5 pho bowls?
author: Tina T.

description:
The bun bo hue here is a bit of cop out - no pork hock, no pork blood, no cabbage.  I don't like pork hock, so that's fine.  

What they do have going for them is the soup.  It's pretty good, and in the northwest corner of the city, the other bun bo hue options are closed by 8:30 p.m. on a week night.  They also accept credit cards.
author: Erika C.

description:
This is, hands down, my favorite pho place and I am so lucky it's close to my apartment.  Just goes to show you that you can sometimes get an awesome meal from a "3.5 star average" place.  

I always get the same thing, though. And it's always outstanding.  Rare beef + beef ball pho.  The beef is plentiful and, as I always get it to go, it's always on the side and I can add it myself to still keep it a bit rare.  However, the real stand out is the broth.  I recently took a pho cooking class and, while my broth was pretty good, I'll never make it as good as authentic pho broth.  And pho is all about the broth...and this place is stellar.  

In fact...I'm going to have pho for dinner tonight. Come on, five o'clock.
author: Shannon B.

description:
The same people are always working, no wonder it's closed Mondays. She even remembers me "I always order the coconut", that is correct.
Imperial Rolls to start and #13- Pho with rare beef. I prefer less noodles and more brothe, since the noodles fill me up before I finish. This is not a dish to be attempted for takeout, unless you have a giant bowl at home. Perfect for a cold San Francisco day.
author: Jenna P.

description: Just what the doctor ordered - I was sick and craving pho and this was just where I needed it when I needed. Its a very simple ambiance, very fast service, and delicious food. I can't speak to authenticity all too well, but I know it felt authentic and tasted great and was absurdly inexpensive. Will definitely be coming back. We had the fresh spring rolls, shrimp pho, and chicken and beef noodle dish (#26). All were delicious, and the pho was enough for 2 meals (which I then proceeded to save it for :) )
author: Elena F.

description:
***Low Down***
Bomb ass Vietnamese restaurant in the heart of the Polk Street corridor!  It's quite a large restaurant with many tables and can accommodate a larger party.  The menu is pretty typical with several varieties of pho, bun bo hue, seafood soup, rice plates, and appetizers.  Prices are very reasonable.  It's busy but never too crowded and no wait time.  Service is very fast and very friendly. Parking in and around Polk gulch is spotty.  The neighborhood is colorful with loads of shops and restaurants and one of my favorite hoods in the entire city!

***Show Down***
OK, let me start off by saying Vietnamese food is my absolute favorite cuisine of all time!  I can eat Vietnamese food every day if I could.  I used to come here 3-5 times a week for lunch when I worked in Russian Hill and I really got to know the staff very well :-).  I usually go for the pho with all the fixin's.  Their bun bo hue is awesome as is their seafood soup with glass noodles. The rice plate with grilled pork or three spices chicken and imperial roll is fabulous.  Unlike many Vietnamese restaurants I've experienced with impersonal staff that just drops off and takes away your dishes without even the slightest hint of a smile, the staff here is incredibly friendly and remembers you and what you usually order!  The place is also pretty clean. This is one of my favorite Vietnamese joints in the city.  I highly recommend you come dine here!
author: Tara T.

description: Yum. Pho is still good. The bun noodles w/ bbq beef is amazing as well.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
It'll do the trick, but you won't write home about it.

This is the place to go when you don't feel like braving the dodgy 'loin of Little Saigon--especially at night nor do you want to trek to Clement street.

They only offer one size bowl and the atmosphere is super casual. The service is ok as well as the food ( no poisoning experiences here). 

I'd give it 3.5 if I could but not quite a 4.
author: Desiree P.

description: Perfect pho for cold days with great service and a good price. Definitely recommend this place.
author: Liz D.

description:
Not the best bowl of pho I've ever had but it gets the job done when you don't want to go to the TL. 

Added Bonus:  Me and the husband ate a ton of the rare steak in pho and as an appie...no food poisoning. 

If the husband liked pho, I'd eat here more often.
author: Kiristen R.

description: Worst place for Vietnamese pho ever. The broth is blend. Even worse than the instant pho noodle that I make at home. The fried rice is awful too. Didnt worth the high price.
author: Mathy N.

description: The Pho was good, the broth was well seasoned and had a lot of pork wontons, sliced pork and ground chicken in it. I could only give three stars because of the service. The lady was nice but not very attentive. The restaurant was not busy and it took her a long time to come take my order and refill my drink. If you want a good cheap meal and aren't in a rush this a good place.
author: Cajun R.

description:
Pho Vietnam is a great place to escape the cold winter (I mean summer) days in San Francisco. Conveniently located on Polk Street between California and Pine, Pho Vietnam is the perfect place to stop in for a quick bite when running errands or carry-out after work. Their Pho has also been known to magically cure hangovers and the flu, like all good Pho should. 

Pho Vietnam is open everyday from 10am -10pm and run by a nice family who seem to always be at the restaurant. The service is friendly and the food is served fast. The restaurant is minimally decorated and screams neighborhood gem. I don't think the interior has been updated since the restaurant was first opened sometime in the 80's (or at least that's what decade the decor is from). The photos on the walls of different palces in Asia are good eye candy and quite entertaining if you've traveled there before. 

The Pho really is fantastic. My favorite is the chicken broth base the beef broth is a close second. Each Pho comes with a bountiful side dish of bean sprouts, mint, jalapenos, and lemon slices. On the table is an assortment of sauces to dress up your Pho from Sriracha sauce and soy to vinegar and fish sauce. Also on the table are two types of chopsticks, green plastic reusable chopsticks for the environmentally conscious and wooden disposable chopsticks for the germ-a-phobes. 

Pho Vietnam is the best Pho available in Nob Hill. With so many competitors in the Tenderloin's Little Saigon, its good that Nob Hill has its own go-to Pho place open late. Stop on by Pho Vietnam and you will not be disappointed in their Pho, Pho Sure!
author: Alice S.

description:
Really liked this place.. Cheap, fast and has great vegetarian options!
I have had their vegetarian imperial rolls which they serve with lettuce, shredded carrot and rice noodles so you can eat them as lettuce wraps.. great way to make a fried appetizer into a somewhat healthier and filling entree.
Their vegetarian chow mein is pretty nice as well, has lots of veggies and tastes pretty good.
author: Aditya M.

description: Excellent service with a smile. The best pho in town. Never too busy. Great people watching from the window. Perfect date spot for a gal who isn't too snobby. I wish they played music in here tho. Still I try and eat here at least once a week. Pho is the best hangover cure and really good for you. Sprouts alkaline the broth. Basil has healing properties. And green onion is a disinflationary. Probably one of the best things you can eat except when MSG and too much salt added. I wished they used a better sriracha that didn't have chemicals.
author: Miles G.

description: I was drunk and starving by 9pm that is no bueno. My friends raved about the Bun no hue here with clear noodles make sure, with clear noodles!! OK got it! It was delicious, ate the whole bowl literally look at my photo. After Pho soups I usually leave with crazy dry mouth from all the salt but I was ok, no dry mouth, good sign. We also for the pork spring roll with peanut sauce it was good! The waitress was also very nice.
author: Karen T.

description: I think I'm going to start getting a little more critical as I've been handing out four and five stars pretty liberally. This place is good not great. Certainly not as good as most of the spots in little Saigon, but conveniently located and I don't have to dodge drug dealers while walking there. Had an awful experience with the pho GA (this soggy noodle weirdness), switched to beef and I'm much happier. They take credit cards, which is good since it's on the pricier side considering the portions. Fast service is perfect for when I need to sneak a bowl in.
author: Anthony T.

description: 2.5 stars. No complaints from me. Got take out here with a co worker. Both of us got the BBQ pork vermicelli.
