What I noticed first hand while I was scarfing my face was the pork to noodle ratio. Most of the time there's too much noodle and not enough pork. Not here- I had more pork than noodles.  That's a good thing, right?The pork itself was nicely marinated and cooked without having too much fat . Want to come back and try the pho on a rainy/cloudy day.
author: Mimie L.

description: This place is clean and fast. I ordered the typical beef ball noodle and it tastes as good as any other good pho restaurants. This place is the spot to go if you need a quick lunch.
author: Thomas M.

description:
Winter time is classic Pho season.  Nothing warms you up more than a steamy hot bowl of brothy goodness and delicious add-ins. 

It was my first time trying this place, and I found it really enjoyable.  The portions are huge, the prices are fair, and the food has flavor.  

Also don't miss out on the spring rolls, the rice paper is the perfect texture and the shrimp is plump.  Oh yeah, the peanut sauce is amazing too!
author: Bobby L.

description: Had the Pho with Brisket and Rare Beef (#10) - tasty and ample portion size! Service was efficient and not unfriendly, no atmosphere, but I'd definitely come back for the satisfying and reasonably priced food!
author: Michel P.

description:
Jojo emailed me and asked if I wanted to meet up for lunch, specifically pho.

I said "Pho sho! Where?"   

He said "Pho Vietnam on Polk."  

I was all "Okay."

Wow!  It was delicious. 

I ordered:
Vietnamese spring rolls -- YUMMY!
Pho Ga (chicken rice noodle soup served in chicken broth) - DE-LISH!

Excellent service. No frills. Priced just right. No drama. Just good food.

Fan-pho-ckingtastic!!!!  Gimme more.
author: Joel G.

description:
This place is all kinds of magic - making hangovers disappear with the wave of a chopstick, a douse of sriracha, a gulp of some veggie pho, and a sip from a fresh purple coconut...

What? Purple coconut?  Yup.  I got a coconut here with purple innards. You've heard of blue balls? Well this place has purple nuts.  Huh?  This is making no sense.  Ok, so maybe my hangover isn't gone...  True story about the purple coconut, though
author: Nicole K.

description: Best pho in town! Fast friendly service. The imperial rolls are so good too. I don't know what's in them but the sauces and all the fixings it comes make it that much more amazing!  Yum! Can't wait to come here again!
author: Monique Q.

description:
Update!! This place is open on Sundays!

Great Pho and has vegetarian Pho, which is hard to fine.
author: B B.

description:
Ahhh pho.  No, I didn't just sneeze but thanks for asking. Jillian R. and I were looking for heart-warming pho soup, and there were two options in the area that came up. Option A turned out to be a huge flop (i.e. a tray of raw chicken chillin' on the floor, right next to where customers were walking by to the bathroom. One look at that and we were out the door!)

Nearly a block away, we saw the sign for Option 2: Pho vietnam. Long story short: $9 got me 1/2 order of shrimp spring rolls and vegetarian pho with chicken broth. Incredible deal.

The rolls were great, the mint was especially aromatic. The peanut dipping sauce left me a little disappointed but not bad. The soup came with a side of the typical bean sprouts, basil and chile slices (jalapeno?) for a little kick. In all, I couldn't finish the whole thing because I wasn't all that hungry to begin with, so I was excited to walk away with leftovers.
author: Alyssa G.

description: Our vacation treck turns into a hunt for a good pho place in northern california...pho vietnam taste ok and the portion is fairly large.  My daughter and I would rate this place a 3.5 stars....
author: LT T.

description: Decent food. Pretty cheap comparing to those Pho places on Clement Street or in Chinatown. Their broth for Pho tastes a lot better than the joints in those specified locations. I think I could call it one of the best Pho places in the Downtown Area.
author: Alex L.

description:
Niece invited me to her friend's birthday party. It's great to meet her friends, but I have the toughest duty of the evening: "the designated driver." One of her friends has just turned 21 and obviously there will be drinking involve.  

"It's about time Matt met some new friends!" (They're too young for me.)

But first the both of us and a couple of niece's friends landed here for a quick bite before we meet up with niece's other friend's. One of the friends and I had the #7, which is the XL (of course) Combo Beef soup. For $8.25, the large bowl contained beef pieces and tendon, noodles in a tasty beef broth. My soup also comes with a side of bean sprouts, basil leaves, sliced lime and jalapeno peppers. That bowl was very filling and the soup was very flavorful. 

Niece had #39; Lemongrass Chicken over rice. Her $8.00 rice plate had the spiced chicken, cut up egg rolls, sliced vegetables and rice. Her plate looks really good and her happy face proved it. On my next visit, I might get her rice-plate. The other friend had the grilled pork and egg rolls over cold vermicelli noodles. I don't know the number, but I'm sure you know what noodle bowl I'm talking about. 

Since I was the designated driver for the night, the three of them for once, paid my meal. This is a pretty clean restaurant with the Dept. of Public Health score of: 95 last checked in June.
author: Matt G.

description:
Nothing says "everything is OK" like a hot piping bowl of Pho.  Especially when you are sick, it is raining outside and freezing, you are alone and feeling lonely and depressed. And worst of all, hungry.
This place has helped me out of a couple of deep funks purely by putting a large bowl of delicate broth, fresh herbs and veggies and a bottle of Sriracha in front of me. It is fast and relatively cheap. 
The rest of their menu is not as good...Ive also tried the spring rolls (2 stars) and the cabbage salad (2.5 stars). 
The food, atmosphere and service are a solid 3 stars but I am rounding up for the fact that I have always left this place feeling much better than when I walked in...my skin warmed from the inside from that big bowl of hot Pho.
author: Nilu r.

description:
Pho restaurants in Little Saigon area are better, but this one stay open later.

Generally speaking, Pho for the most part tastes the same unless they are doing something extraordinary with it anyways.  Everything is about average here-- from price, amount of food, and taste.  I love the pictures up on the wall here.  If you've taken photos in Asia before, you'll recognize a lot of these scenaries.

Bottom line: Pho Vietnam is consistent, and you'll always leave content.  I'm not sure if this is a place that you necessarily scope out.  It's just there.
author: Eugene L.

description: I have been on a pho kick lately. There are a good three days in any given week that that's ALL I can think of eating for dinner. I've tried a few places in the city that I like and thought I'd give nearby Pho Vietnam a whirl! For the pricing and the convenience, I thought it was pretty good. My boyfriend and I each had pho + split an order of spring rolls and spent a whopping $22 for dinner. You really can't beat that! My seafood pho was pretty good -- pretty flavorful broth. Spring rolls are one of my most favorite things and while theirs were good, they definitely weren't great. I'm not sure what normally goes in them, but their seemed to lack a bit of flavor (no worries though - peanut sauce makes everything delicious). I'm sure I'll go back because of convenience, but normally wouldn't make the top of my list.
author: Shannon E.

description:
Love their broth & spring rolls. The pho is good. They have a lot more to offer, which is great to get non pho lovers to join.

They let me purchase just a side of broth when I crave it & don't want to commit to pho, but no matter how many times I've ordered it, the pricing has still been random.
author: Rah F.

description:
Came in here all stuffed up and with a crazy craving for a delicious bowl of pho. I know everyone's into Turtle Tower, but I needed a serious SOUTHERN style pho fix. 

Yeh, it's sort of dingy looking, but what pho place isn't?? I got a half order of summer rolls that were tightly wrapped (it kills me when you bite into a weakly wrapped roll) and by the time I was done with one, my steaming bowl of pho was placed in front of me. AAHHHH. Delish.

The broth was flavorful enough that I could taste it despite my stuffy nose, so that's a plus. The beef was ok...my brisket was a little too fatty for my taste, but whatever. I ate around it. 

Price was right, credit cards are a-ok, service was speedy...you bet I'll be back to give this place another try with fully functional tastebuds.
author: Karena Q.

description:
Not cheap for what it is.

A $6 bowl of Bún bò Hu (without tendon, please!) for $8, and add on two of the tiniest Imperial Rolls you have ever seen for $1.95. Call me picky but there are much better bargains in this town.

The food itself? Well, I guess no one, not even white people, order Spicy Beef Noodle Soup unless they want it spicy -- which I did -- and, boy was it! Just the ticket to clear our your sinuses from The Annual San Francisco December Headcold.

The place was clean. Not very busy.

Would I eat there again? Sure! Would I go out of my way? Absolutely not.
author: BigJohnS F.

description: I go here at least once a week on my lunch break to eat a big hearty bowl of Pho. The price for pho is a little high, something I'm not used to but in my view, it's worth the price. Usually not a lot of people go here during the day, so service is prompt and you get your pho in no time. They do accept credit card and cash, so don't worry about using your plastic but if you like the food, leave a good tip because this is the best service for pho!
author: Jonas E.

description:
I've been here this place several times.  I keep coming back for their good food. These are the two items that I keep ordering.

Won ton soup:  The broth tastes really good! I love eating this noodle soup especially when I have a cold.  It warms you up really nicely.
BBQ Pork rice plate:  The pork is always cooked perfectly.  

The service is nice and friendly.  I will come back again hopefully soon!
author: M Y.

description:
Solid pho in the area!

Let me preface that the food is good- nothing out of the orderinary/amazing, but good.  I'm usually in the area and this is definitely my go-to joint if I'm feeling like Vietnamese food.

The pho and bun dishes are all tasty and cheap.  The rolls are delish!  I've never had to wait to be seated or to get service.  

Definitely worth a visit if you're wandering around the area!
author: Christine K.

description:
Consistent food; clean tables; quick service; super hot
broth and cold crispy veggies; no minimums for credit cards.  What else do you really need in a pho place?  

I would die of happiness if they delivered.
author: Joyce W.

description:
Came here with my friends and ordered the BBQ pork on vermicili.  Excellent size for the price and it was delicious.

The only downside was the snide comment made by then waitress when we wanted to split the bill 3 ways.  She said under her breath, "You should have said something before you ordered." How rude!
author: Mike L.

description:
The magical pho at Pho Vietnam has been known to cure hangovers in one swift slurp. My go-to pho place, is a no frills simple pho restaurant. The location is in the main thoroughfare of Polk street, and in turn can be a heinous adventure in finding parking. I'm a huge fan of the simple chicken pho, which runs about $8.00. If you need to, they make it extremely easy to take out on the go. 

My only issue was when they went on vacation for about an entire month, with no notice whatsoever. No sign, no answering machine. I'm quite happy they're back now, and realized again how much I love the place in their brief absence.
author: Melinda S.

description: Crab claw and shrimp noodle soup. Boom. (Very important: be sure to request phō noodles.)
author: Aaron E.

description:
My review might be a bit biased based on the following story that doesn't really have anything to do with the quality of the food, but it doesn't hurt 'em, just left me with fond memories...

One of my friends from home was visiting for a few days and he met my roomie and me here when he got in. BEST FIRST IMPRESSION EVER: within one minute of hometown friend sitting down, roomie was caught off guard by the level of spiciness of the hot sauce she had added and sprayed noodles across the table all over me and hometown friend. Gross and hilarious all at the same time. She's going to be harassed about that one for a long long time.

So, fond memories aside, the pho was good. And there was a lot of it. And a lot of fresh bean sprouts. And I liked the broth. And the price was reasonable. And the service was good. And the spicy things to add in must be pretty spicy. Will be back again, though hopefully without a noodle spraying incident. One of those is enough for me, unless I'm sitting on the same side as the sprayer.
author: Kim B.

description: Ordered the vermicelli with grilled pork and spring rolls. Noodles were soggy, pork looked like charred pieces of fat. Definitely tasted better vermicelli.
author: Tony H.

description:
My Vietnamese friend TP had a craving for pho so when he suggested Pho Vietnam, I naturally assumed it had to be good since he has high standards.

I tried the pho with rare beef slices (no tendon, tripe, and undefinable parts). Came with the usual bean sprouts, basil leaves, and lime. The noodles were ok, a little stuck together. Meat slices were fine, but seemingly a bit lower grade. Really enjoyed the broth though which was nice and naturally sweet. I drank a lot of it.

Service was friendly since the owner liked speaking Vietnamese with my friend. This is a quick fix to pho craving, but honestly I've had better.
author: Cindy W.

description:
Went here with a friend for a casual dinner. Was easy to get a table and service was good.

The pho was pretty tasty but nothing too special.

All in all a solid choice if you're feeling low-key.
author: Rachel R.

description:
This my neighborhood Pho restaurant when I don't want to head into the Tenderloin's abysmal swamp of humanity. 

The place is bright and cheery, the women working their are friendly and the pho is just fine with a good size portion of fresh basil, beansprouts and lime on the side.

Beyond the pho, I also recommend the carpaccio.
author: Pineapples D.

description:
Rainy day=pho 

I like this place. It is the only decent pho restaurant in my area (Marina/Russian Hill). Today was a perfect day for this soupy noodle goodness. 

I would give this place 3.5 stars because of the lack of consistency. On some days, the soup seems bland and the meat is chewy and fatty. However, this time, I was surprisingly pleased. Soup was just the way I wanted it. The meat was really really tender. For about $7.50, you get a hearty bowl of pho. Although I don't understand the extra cost for meat on the side. No other restaurant that I know of charges. I think that part is lame. 

Look out for specials near the register.
author: Molly T.

description: Good pho - not over the top, but solid choice in this city - Turtle Tower is still number one!
author: Richard D.

description:
I found a shard of bottle glass in my noodles that ended up in my noodles the last time I ate there.  When I showed it to the staff they took my bowl away and made no apologies whatsoever.  They even charged me for the food, despite me showing them my bloody inside lip.  

I won't ever go back.  Eat with caution here.
author: Richard P.

description:
Great pho. I've eaten here several times and everytime it is good.
The spring rolls are good, the pho is consistent, and the service is pretty good and friendly too.
author: Ryan R.

description:
As far as the pho goes, the broth is excellent from start to finish - no need for the globs of garlic chili or dashes of fish sauce. The meat in the beef noodle soup is of good quality and plentiful. Good service, standard decor. Conveniently located near the Polk Gulch watering holes, AMC theaters, and the Great American Music Hall.

Why three stars? Well, 5-star restaurant pho is easily found in Vietnam; 4-star restaurant pho is prevalent within the confines of Westminster or San Jose. I'd actually give Pho Vietnam 3 1/2 stars if I could. Chao!
author: Be N.

description:
I really liked this pho. Service was perfunctory, as one would expect. They were a little light on the basil/lime, but the dish itself was tasty. 

ps WTF is it about Pho places that diners think they can yabber away on their cellphones at super loud volumes and not offend anyone there? Really, is that necessary?
author: Dina G.

description: Holy MSG! I think this place probably ranks highest in aftermath thirst attacks. I can't complain though...I still enjoyed my meals. I've reviewed plenty of other places serving MSG soup, and they were less than satisfying. This wouldn't be my top choice when craving for Pho, but sometimes when I want something slightly different, like their "Hu Tieu Dai Ba Nam Sa Dec (seafood, quail egg, slices of pork, ground pork, spare rib in a clear rice noodle soup)"...this is where I go. I prefer this slippery choice dry with soup on the side so I can add my concoction of spicy things. It can be a bit greasy, but I kinda like that sort of thing.
author: Helen L.

description: Veggie spring rolls were lousy, veggie pho quite good, but I was put off when the waiter loudly commented on the apparently OBSCENE amount of food I ate! Totally inappropriate. Will not return.
author: Liz L.

description: The pho is goood! We tried many places because we love pho. This might be our favorite, or second favorite Vietnamese  restaurant in the city. The owners are nice and the service is good. Cheap for SF.
author: Erika C.

description:
Came here on a whim since we were in the area. The Pho was tasty, flavorful, and had nice tendons, meat, etc. The price was a tiny bit higher than I would have wanted, but not by unreasonable amounts. I still got very full!

We also had vegetarian Spring rolls that contained lightly fried tofu's inside. Very good. We drank Vietnamese hot coffee. Boy is that stuff strong, and good.

Overall, the place was clean, nice bowls & cups. I'll come back again if I am in the area but I tend to frequent other Pho places closer to home.
author: H L.

description: I eat pho regularly, and like to visit different pho restaurants. I have been to Pho Vietnam multiple times because it is close to where I live, and everytime it is "ok". I got take-out this past week on my way home from work, and it was  terrible. The noodles were old and had been sitting in the box for a long time. The herbs/veggies were also days old - they were wilted and you could tell they had been sitting in the box with the noodles for days. I will not be coming back here.
author: Elizabeth S.

description:
This is one of the few Vietnamese places in the area that is not buried in the TL. +1 star for that alone. Sometimes I want some pho, but don't want to dodge bullets and jump over passed out bums. It's located on Polk Street, which has at least 50% fewer crackheads.

The food isn't bad, but it is over priced for what it is. Charging for tea? Come on now. The pho isn't bad, but those tiny little runts they call imperial rolls are just sad. If I held up my fist and stuck up my middle finger the imperial rolls would have been smaller than the finger.
author: Jordan M.

description: I found this place on Yelp while waiting for my Toyota car to get serviced. The place looked authentic which I felt welcomed and at home. The server was nice and the pho (Shrimp, Squid, Fish Ball, Fish Cake, And Imitation Crab With Rice Noodles) I always order at any vietnamese restaurant was very tasty. Seafood was well cooked and side vegetables were fresh. Definitely going back to this place when having the next car service ;D
author: Maitai N.

description:
When PHO VIETNAM opened they were rockin' GOOD!

Now. Not so much!

The VEGGIE PHO is lacking in taste. (At least they didn't make it in chicken/meat broth and LIE. But it tastes like NO broth at all...plain water!)  There are lots of veggies and nicely prepared rice noodles, though one will need some soy-sauce to spice them up! Price is kinda steep for an easy meal one can prepare at home. 

The VEGGIE SPRINGS rolls are good. Enjoyed them though I wish they would cut them into smaller pieces. (The waitress said NO!) 

As for the FRIED VEGGIE SPRING ROLLS...omygawd...GREASE CITY...these little morsals lacked taste, shined & oozed oil....YUCK. 

The decor which used to be clean and sharp for a plain restaurant,  now has hit the 'icky' phase.  

A little too scary.
author: Addadada A.

description:
Came for: pho in convenient and good location
Will come back for: sure

The few times I've been here, I've found the service good and friendly.
The pho is good and consistent.  I enjoyed the broth (very important in making a good soupy noodle dish), which was flavorful without being too oily/fatty.  I recall the portion on the more generous side.  All in all good, but nothing to write home about among the many pho selections.

When the palate craves pho, there's Chinatown, Richmond, Sunset or the TL.  This is a good option especially as one that sits outside of the TL.
author: Carol K.

description: didn't like the smell when I walked in, smelled like it has not been mop for months, food was awful, ordered pho and they give you soo little meat, I never seem that before! Never come here again.
author: Kristen X.

description:
Really good, clean, uncrowded Viet restaurant on Polk Street.  Food taste great, and it comes quick and hot.
  Some have commented that the woman is not friendly , but she's fine;  just doesn't fawn over you.
Again, very pleasant place with excellent food.
author: Charlie W.

description:
Pho ga is the best when done right. I typically leave my fave pho place with nothing left in the bowl except the chopsticks.

Unfortunately, Pho Vietnam misses it's mark.  Can you say MSG?

the broth was ok, the chicken was ok and the fresh vegetables that accompany the pho were wilted.

If you want ok, then check it out. For me, I won't come back.
author: Vanessa J.

description:
The staff were so, friendly when I walked in the door. The food is authenic so, it hasn't been "white washed", yet. The soup came with all the traditional items, it was good, and filling.
I also got  the chicken with rice, the rice was a bit squishy, and the chicken kinda fatty. It'll be only soup when I go back.
The place is inexpensive, and good, great for a rainy SF day.
author: Nathan M.

description:
When I tell the Boy that I want to come here for the nth time in a single week, he'll haughtily ask 'What the pho is wrong with you?', to which I respond 'Pho you! I just love the pho there so!'. 

But seriously, service is fast, food is delicious (I dare you to sip the pho broth and not shudder with delight), and the sriricha is within easy reach. I recommend the spring rolls (not your average fried variety, but rather the ones wrapped in translucent skins and filled with grilled shrimp and lettuce) and #7 and #29.
author: Annie M.

description: Still producing the best Vietnamese won ton soup this side of the Mekong Delta.  It's raining -- go get some now!
author: Laurence W.

description:
2.5/5

"Good enough" pretty much captures the essence of the Pho and of this restaurant. 

The atmosphere is clean and functional, you get in, sit down, and order fairly quickly. The service lacks warmth, but is prompt. 

I ordered a standard beef pho, it was delivered rather quickly. This place is a bit odd in that they only have one size, and that all pho of that size is about $7.25 ($7.94 after tax) -- the size is moderate, a little smaller than most places mediums and a little larger than most places smalls. However, most places mediums are at or below this price, which makes this not the best value in the world. They get 2.5 stars for the portions.

The beef is averagely cut -- the knifework at both Pho 2000 and Pho Tan Hoa is better, but the cut is a bit above Turtle Tower. The quality of the meat is okay, but it was not particularly memorable, and the portions were a little light (partially because the bowl itself was not very generous). They get 2.5 stars for beef.

The broth could have been a bit hotter, and was a bit light on the flavor, probably bit heavy on star anise or cinnamon, and it doesn't really capture all the flavor of the beef. It was alright.  They get 2.5 stars for the broth. A star is then deducted because I saw a hair in my broth. No, I don't think it ruins or pollutes the pho in and of itself, but it hints at less than professional cooking, and heightened the "less than average" overall experience of the visit.

I didn't try any of the drinks -- when I go to have pho, I usually only get pho, no spring rolls, no frills, no detours-- straight to business. So, this review doesn't comment on those.

It's not great, it's not amazing, it's not spectacular, but it is definitely "good enough".

While it would get 2 stars, I will give it 2.5 for a very simple reason -- the hours. It's open until 10 and it's near me. Most other good pho places close early (as they are in the TL) so this means when I get a random 9pm craving for pho, and nothing else will work -- I have this. So that's something.

I'll check out a lot of other places and give this place another go in the future to see if it was just a bad night.
author: David H.

description:
Dear owner

1. your service is horrible. Every single of your wait staff...including owner himself treat me like a dirt. You have to learn some manner first before you open this place. I never ever leave a comment on yelp...but this is just becomning unbearable. If you want a better review...you should seriously retrain your wait staff...and owner himself should learn some manner!
author: Mike P.

description: What?  I'm not sure why there are so many high ratings for this place.  Maybe it's close to where some of you live or maybe not worth walking a few blocks south to the tenderloin?  The pho here is pretty expensive (~$10) for what I consider a smaller bowl than other places.  The broth seemed like it came from a soup packet of MSG.  The meat was not good either.  I guess it's one of the places open late at night and a couple of you wouldn't go down to the tenderloin.  Understood, but I don't think the food lived up to what I was looking for compared to the price.
author: Jon K.

description: My girlfriends and I came here pretty frequently after getting hammered the night before.  It's cheap and helps ease the pain of the day after when it's not painful enough for a bloody mary.
author: Suz L.

description:
I do think it's funny that they're calling the Tenderloin Little Saigon these days when the crack addicts are thicker than flies, but places like Pho Vietnam makes me think it deserves the name. They serve up steaming hot bowls of traditional pho for your slurping pleasure.

Today was monumental because I tried beef pho for the first time. We asked for thin slices of rare beef on the side, and cooked them in the broth as we ate, so they were nice and pink and tender. Be sure to squeeze in the lemon and throw in the jalapeño for that zing! 

Beef today. Sinewy tendons tomorrow!
author: Nicole G.

description:
Wanted to try this place for some time now because they have bun bo hue.  Finally made it in and it smelled promising.  The place is spacious and clean.  

I knew what I wanted but checked out their menu anyway.  Hubby was debating between the combo pho and the seafood clear noodle but given it's our first visit, he decided to go with the standard.  

We had:
iced coffee w/ milk - $2.95 - it was pretty good

imperial rolls (egg rolls) - $6.95 - you get 6 with lettuce leaves, shredded carrots and a little rice noodle with the fish sauce - pretty good

bun bo hue - $7.75 - I asked for it to be very extra spicy.  When it arrived, I was disappointed.  It was not spicy.  It didn't have any pork feet - whole or sliced, no pork blood - instead it was served w/ slices of meat similar to those you find in pho.  They also don't have the right condiments w/ it.

combo pho - $8.25 - the bowl is large but there's not much noodles although the flavor is not bad.

The older lady who brings the food to the table is a lot nicer and friendlier than the ladies in the front.
author: Gloria H.

description:
I love running through traffic like a chicken with my head cut off in Central Hanoi.

I also love getting ripped off by cyclo drivers, who like to take advantage of horrible accents. Apparently 15000 dong means 50000 dong.

Additionally, I love Vietnamese taxi drivers who claim that the street you WANTED to go to had a "name change" 2 months ago and who swear that the hotel he brought you to is indeed the one you wanted to go to, even though it coincidentally had a "name change" too.

But most of all, I love that Vietnam introduced me to this incredible brothy noodle soup which is soon to make me a skinny little b*%#^! PHO SHO! Actually, for all you peeps out there who don't know - please note: PHO is pronounced FUH and it is soooo good.

Anyway, "Pho Vietnam" has some pretty good Pho - but you can't really compare it to the real stuff in Vietnam. It's just not the same. And no matter how good it is anywhere else, it will probably just never seem as good as Pho in Ho Chi Mihn or Hanoi after a long day of struggles on the streets.  Biased? Yes.

Oh... one more thing: I love how Pho in SF is 10x more expensive than in Vietnam.  Ahn yeu San Fran! Bitter? Maybe.
author: Allison N.

description:
Pho Vietnam--HOLLA HOLLA HOLLA (from a novice pho-enthusiast)!

I've been sick since the Memorial Day weekend and have had glands swollen to the size of golf balls! After days of bitchin' and complaining about being hungry, sick, and not knowing what to eat, my bf suggests we get pho. What a genius!

Vegetarian pho ($7.25):
-- Came in a near-translucent broth, which I feared might be flavorless in comparison to the beef broth my bf got, so I quickly appeased those fears by squeezing in a bunch of that delicious plum sauce and sriracha! So good!
-- Comes w/ carrots, broccoli, cabbage, tofu, and noodles
-- Added the string beans, jalapenos, and whatever that heavenly aromatic leafy herb was, and squirted that lemon wedge in there!

The result: 
++ FUCKIN' DELICIOUS! I haven't had something HIT THE SPOT like that in a long time! I am completely obsessed with it now.  
++ Fast and pretty friendly service
++ Big, bright, and clean dining area
++ Great location (a.k.a. it's not in the TL so I can come here in the middle of the night by myself)
++ Cheap! One bowl serves as two meals. No matter how long I was SHOVELING IT INTO MY TRAP, it didn't seem to get smaller. Bowl = HUGE. I L-O-V-E leftovers!

Lemme get at ya, Pho Vietnam! Holla!
author: Kristine W.

description:
OH MY PHO!
There's nothing fancy about this place but the food is delicious, reliable and cheap.

My favorite is the tofu pho.  It's the healthiest dish possible.  Cubes of tofu (not fried) and comes with lots of fresh veggies (broccoli, cabbage and carrots).  For more flavor, add chicken.  It's an extra $3 but adds tons of flavor.  Plus it's white meat...healthy!
author: Betty Y.

description:
We were in search of a pho fix and didn't want to travel far from home, so we decided to give this joint a go.  Upon entering you see this very cafeteria like atmosphere with unflattering lighting, numbered tables, and there were only 2 other people sitting down.  A little skeptical at first, but sat it out.  Started with the imperial rolls which were good, a little greasy for my liking though.  We both just got rare steak pho for our entrees, and when they brought out the acoutrements we knew we were in for an experience.  There was a large pile of sprouts, a quite skimpy basil selection, some jalapenos and 2 lemon slices.  The veggies seemed a bit tired, not the fresh delicious ones I'm used to.  And lemon??  I guess I don't know what is authentic but I'm used to limes and this just caught me off guard.  

On to the soup.  One size fits all, and also a bit more expensive than you'd expect.  The broth was alright... it had a hint of something I'm not really used to and didn't really hit the spot.  Lets just say that I wasn't drinking the remaining broth after finishing the solid goods in the bowl as usual.  The meat was subpar as well, it was pretty tough and there was also a shortage of total meat supplies in both of our bowls.  Overall, it was an ok experience but I will definitely be putting in a little more work to get my next pho phix!
author: William B.

description:
there are a few things that makes a good bowl of pho; the broth, the noodle, the meats, and lastly the green basil. My biggest gripe was the noodle, it was way overcooked and too soft. I forgot to taste the broth before adding my sauces, so i can't give an honest opinion. They skimmed out on the meat combination, so i was left with mostly overcooked noodle (which cost next to nothing). Another biggest thing that disappoint was the basil. Most people don't know this but the basil isn't just a garnish, it's what makes 1/3 of the pho flavor. The basil should be fresh and abundant as possible. It's the small things like this that show if they have any consideration at all.
The basil was wilted and seems like ready to be thrown out. Considering they are the only pho in the nob hill/van ness area, i wouldn't come back if i have a choice. The service was also only okay. Maybe lack of competitions lead to lack of quality.
author: Tuan B.

description:
I couldn't in good conscience not warn people about this place, my girlfriend insisted I try it again before reviewing it. Ok, it still sucks.

Why would anyone eat here when Little Saigon is a few crack infested blocks away? I have to say I was extremely confused about all the great reviews on this place.

The super basic "Fresh Spring Roll" was not fresh in the slightest. The bean sprouts were brown and tasted rotten, the smell was so bad I couldn't bring it to my face. The shrimp? Well I won't even go  there... and the rice paper was most definitely not homeade.

The Pork and Vermicelli bowl was so salty, I had to assume it was covering up something. The fried "Imperial Rolls" were soggy and tasted previously frozen.

We had a few other dishes, none were good.

In short, this is the "fast food" of the Vietnamese Industry. Why eat this? Just because it is in the nicer part of town, doesn't mean you should waste your time. Grab the pepper spray and brave Little Saigon. Its well worth it over this joint.

And as a final note, the service was atrocious. I don't know if they just hate gays or what, but we were super polite and quiet, non-demanding and appreciative... yet they practically threw our food at us. They ignored us for long periods of time, and gave us our check midway through our meal. Then this super creepy Vietnamese grandma character leaned on the bar behind us and kept saying"Good-bye" to us for like the last 30 minutes of our meal until we finally did just give up and leave. Not like we wanted to eat the rest of our food anyway.

If you are a) gay or b) have tastebuds, you shouldn't eat here.
author: Jay M.

description: My favorite pho restaurant in the city, and only a few blocks from my apartment!  The meals are cheap, the portions are huge, the place is clean, and the service is good.  I always get the Pho Ga (chicken pho), but everything looks good!
author: Michelle F.

description: Good Pho...but this place has cockroaches. One came out of the chopstick holder on the table. I saw two on the wall and the old lady came over and smashed it with a paper towel.
author: Chris B.

description:
It was an Herculean effort to get the waitress to smile halfway.

Other than that, the food (five-spiced barbecue chicken with imperial rolls, Hong Kong iced tea lemonade, a.k.a. Arnold Palmer with Panama orange) was good.
author: Inigo M.

description:
I found it.

I found it!
I found it!
I found it!
I found it!
I found it!
I found it!
I found it!
I found it!
I found it!

I looked, and I looked  - and finally, I have fallen upon the one Pho joint in San Francisco that hits the spot for me.  I drove out to No-Man's Land called the Sunset, I went to dingy places, high and low in search of a good bowl of Pho.

Every place failed me in one way or another.

But finally, last night, I found it.  A place I can call "home".  A place I can count on to give me a hot bowl of GOOD PHO with good beef, tendons, and amazing soup with perfect noodles.... and I don't have to drive to San Jose or fly to Westminster to find it.
It's merely 6 blocks from my house.

And -  their spring rolls, while petite, are really well-packed, tight, and not chock full of only noodles.  I love it, this is how I make it at home!

But the Pho.... it was awesome.  

I found it.

I may not have to move out of the Bay Area afterall.
author: Grace K.

description:
I crave this place when Im feeling sick, hungover or just want to warm up on a cold night. I love Pho and theres this little old lady that works there who kicks ass with customer service! 
The food is great! The Pho...sooo deliciouse. I usually get the #10 (rare steak) or the #12. Its only $7.95 for an order of Pho and it totally fills you up!
author: Nene D.

description:
In a nutshell - good food and an okay dining experience.

Big menu, great Pho and other specials that are well priced. No complaints here, but no bells and whistles either...
author: claire s.

description: Service and decor leave something to be desired here but the food is quite tasty.
author: Garret N.

description:
Not just great food, but they couldn't be more welcoming.  Not only is their pho ga the best I've ever tasted (it makes this restaurant one of my "happy places"), but it's like visiting your aunt's kitchen... if your aunt made kick-ass Vietnamese food.

How nice are they?  Two of the staff were taking a break (eating something that was not on the menu) and when I expressed interest in what they were eating, they gave me some. They insisted.  You can't beat that kind of hospitality.

Whenever I'm hungry and close by, I go here, and I've never regretted it.  Neither will you.
author: Alec B.

description:
Since it's the city and not San Jose or Westminster, I didn't expect the pho here to blow my mind, but it was very decent. Far better than Pho Garden in Richmond. I would compare it to the ol' chain, Pho Hoa. Now, I know a lot of ppl rag on Pho Hoa, but its like the starbucks of pho. It's not the greatest, but you know what you're gonna get, and when you're craving pho, it does the job. 

Thumbs up for cleanliness, good service and decent portions for a reasonable 7.25 (I think there's only one size, and its the equivalent of a normal large). Taking off points for chopsticks that always seem to be sticky on one end. I've been here twice, and the pho I had for lunch was noticeably fresher compared to my dinner pho...maybe it was a one-time thing, maybe thats the trend. Both were good regardless. Recommended.
author: Brian N.

description:
Great pho and great fried spring rolls. I recommend the #12 (Pho with beef balls and rare steak). In combo with the fried spring rolls, this is a hangover cure. Everything is fresh and the portions are huge. Prices are reasonable too!

The ambiance of this place is very strange. It has the worst florescent lighting ever and the layout is really bland. I guess this doesn't matter because the food is really good...
author: Bobby D.

description:
The grandma who works here are so cute. She looks like my grandma! I first went there when I had a hungover. The Pho was so-so but the vermicelli was amazing! I also like the raw beef appetizer! 
The only blargh thing is their cilantro is mixed with green onions.. I love my cilantro plain.
author: Miss C.

description: Food is good and is served very fast. My only issue is the waitress there...so serious! Girl, smile once in awhile.
author: Roberto G.

description:
It's kind of fucked up that I measure a Vietnamese restaurant's authenticity by its lack of sanitation. For instance, Tu Lan. Whoa, AUTHENTIC! To be perfectly honest, before they remodeled, it was getting a little too "authentic" if you know what I mean. So when Pho Vietnam opened up on Polk I saw its shiny, non-sticky floor and decidedly free-of-grease-streaked walls as a sign that the food would most likely be a watered down parody of Vietnamese cuisine.

However, upon eating there I found the food to be very tasty. The pho is good and like any decent Vietnamese restaurant it practically comes in a punch bowl. The rice plates are solid and I like the pickled veggies they put on the side. The bun and imperial rolls are not spectacular though and I have yet to find a place as good as Tu Lan for those items.

Overall, decent food without the grimy atmosphere. If you really need some funk to ease your mind I suppose you could forfeit a shower or two before eating here. Just plan on eating alone, you grubby bastard
author: Josua P.

description:
Cold weather is the perfect time for a hot bowl of pho, and Pho Vietnam is a well-priced, decent restaurant choice if you are on Polk Street.  It's also more clean than some Vietnamese places I have been to further into the Tenderloin.

It can get crowded at lunch time, but there are a large number of tables so if you have to wait, it should not be long.

The spring rolls are very good - peanut sauce is more peanut-buttery than I usually like, but the rolls are made perfectly.

The Pho is enormous and tasty - $6.95 for something as big as your head is great a deal in my book (I have a big head).

Food is brought out quickly and service is efficient.  The quality of the food seems better than most, and again, it is nice and clean in the restaurant which always makes me feel good.

If you are new to Vietnamese cuisine, Pho Vietnam is an authentic, yet non-intimidating choice of restaurant.  The menu is very clear, with pictures, and the location does not require you to take any extra cautionary measures.
author: Liz S.

description: Typical pho, vermicelli, and rice plate items on their menu. Portions are hearty for lunch. Try to save room for their fried banana with ice cream. They are little triangles of goodness.
author: Connie C.

description:
It wasn't bad-- a huge bowl of spicy beef soup for 6.95.  Plus some Vietnamese beer, probably the Bud of Vietnam.

My problem was the authenticity.  It was TOO authentic for my American tongue.  I'm complaining about the half ton of tripe in my soup.

All in all it was tasty and a good price, but I probably wouldn't go again unless someone really wanted to get some noodle soup.
author: Rocco B.

description:
I've only ever had the Pho here, and it's always been pretty good.  I usually go here when I'm sick or hungover, and it always makes me feel better. The Pho Ga is decent, but the #9 Pho (rare beef, tripe and tendon) is my fave.

It's no Turtle Tower, but it hits the spot, plus it's cheap and only a few blocks from my house.
author: Kelly L.

description:
Pho Vietnam has average pho at best. The meat was thick enough, though there are other pho places that offer better slices that seem thicker, so nothing memorable as the portions barely kept me full.

Although I've had lesser pho than this place, I would just say this pho restaurant kept me somewhat satisfied, but not overly amused unfortunately.

Unless I'm in the Nob Hill/Tenderloin area and need to cure a craving for pho or a rice plate with hoisin and chicken, I won't go out of my way to get to this place anytime soon.
author: Rob L.

description:
I had lunch with two friends. We came from different directions, ate, and then parted our separate ways.  Two of us ordered the BBQ Chicken Bun (vermicelli noodles) and one ordered the Pork Bun.  The two of us who had the BBQ Chicken ended up with food poisoning (mild) within a few hours after lunch.

The food was good and service fine, and sure, this could happen anywhere, but I will not return.
author: Jack L.

description:
Pho, I love you. 

Why Pho Vietnam receives 5 Stars:

1. They have a small yet satisfying vegetarian selection. 
2. Quick service
3. The vegetarian pho order is always TWICE the size as beef pho 
     noodles. 
4. Only 2 and half blocks from my apt. 

Quick, satisfying and cheap just the way I like it. 
Oh Pho Vietnam you know me so well.
author: MJ T.

description:
Once you taste the spring rolls and pho you won't mind the cafeteria-like setting.  Honestly, it is a pretty charming place and the food is incredible.  Spring rolls made for a perfect, light starter.  Crisp bean sprouts, vermacelli noodles, shrimp and mint are tightly tucked into rice paper and come with a tasty peanut dipping sauce. I'm new to the area but I have tried quite a few pho places and this is by far, the best.  The broth is exquisite and you can really taste all the complex flavors that went into it.  

If you can look past the very casual setting, you are in for an affordable treat.  I'll definitely be going back.  The staff was very friendly and attentive, and I'm excited to try more of what they have to offer.
author: Jackie F.

description:
I am a stranger to Vietnamese Cuisine, though I've eaten enough Thai, Chinese & Japanese to know what ballpark I'm in.

Still, nothing could prepare me for the deliciousness of last night's dinner. I was expecting mediocrity. But when the bill for a delicious dinner for two comes out to $20 -- for two entrees & one appetizer -- you know you've hit a homerun.

We ordered the Thai Eggrolls, which were pretty good. Then the Tofu w/Veggies -- an improvement to very good -- & the Spicy Lemongrass Chicken, which was THE BOMB.

If I lived in the neighborhood, I'd make this a regular joint, no doubt. One of the finest cheap meals I've had in the city in a long time.
author: Pete J.

description:
I'd probably give them 3.5 stars if Yelp would get with the times.  4 is a bit generous, but they were definitely above average ONLY because it felt like there was less MSG and the broth was more home brewed than my staple Pho Hoa.

I'd willingly go back, but I'll be sure to drink more of the soup because the lady was a bit upset I didn't drink enough.  She said it takes a lot of work to make it.
author: James F.

description:
Something you should know about me. I have a huge Phodiction. I mean, huge. All it takes is for me to see something from Vietnam, or to look at someone eating soup, or to see a pair of chopsticks for Christ sake  and the seed is planted and I'm screwed. The idea of this soup crawls around my head until it gets what it wants. It literally has a mind of its own so I'm really not kidding when I say I take my Pho seriously. So seriously I'm telling you now, find somewhere else to get it than this place. Ouch, I know. I'm sorry, but I have to tell you exactly why this place should only be a last resort when you wanna feed that noodle soup addiction.

In my neighborhood, Pho Vietnam is the only Pho place within walking distance (that I know of at least, and believe me we've looked). I know people say that you can go down into the TL and try Turtle Tower, but that is a completely different kind of Pho. That's a no plum sauce, no beef balls no anything I recognize Pho to be kinda place; you'll see that review soon from me I'm sure. Pho Vietnam is where you go when you have no bus money, no cab money, no gas, no car, no friends with a car, no bike, no scooter, no skateboard, no unicycle to go to Kevin's in the Sunset or Pho Garden in the Richmond. You go here if it's been a while and you forgot how much it sucks so you give it a second or a third chance and get beat right back down again. Sure it suffices for a hot bowl of soup on a cold, foggy SF day, but have some standards! You can always go heat up a cup of water at home!

What makes a good Pho place (as many of you know) is the broth. This place has some seriously bland broth. It's missing some spices or something. I made broth at home for Pho and it tasted better alone than theirs will ever. It's like they took a little Hetch Hetchy and splashed some anise pods in there and called it broth. The meat is super tough, like it's the cheapest they could buy and it just tastes sloppy and watered down. The portion size is wonderful, but when you don't really want to eat what's in front of you what's the point in handing me a giant bowl of it? Their appetizers are so-so as well. They don't taste home made, in fact they taste like they bought it at Trader Joe's in the frozen section or something. But every time we go here, we have forgotten how much they suck and always end up ordering the imperial rolls as a swift reminder not to get them again. Man we are suckers for convenience. 

The restaurant itself is really not that nice. Everything is a little outdated and with the Florescent lighting it always looks some kind of dirty in there. The staff is nice enough, in fact they're getting two stars only because of the location and their staff. I've never had a problem with any of them it's just the recipe that sucks. Kinda a big thing to have suck but its true!

Anyways, we used to eat here all the time not knowing that what we were having was an inferior noodle soup. If you are a super fan of this place than more power to you my friend, but I BEG OF YOU, try Pho Garden or Kevin's, just to see that for a cheaper price you can get a bowl of Pho that makes you feel like a kid again. The right broth and meat cuts make me feel like I'm wrapped in a giant blanket snuggling on the couch and I'm playing hooky for the day watching movies in the rain. It's so good, its that kind of good. This place just doesn't give me that feeling, ever...and honestly I don't think it ever will.
author: Sarah L.

description:
Great potential is a terrible thing to waste. 

For every good to excellent Vietnamese restaurant in this town (Mai's, Turtle Tower, Ahn Hong, Saigon Sandwiches), there are 10 mediocre to very bad Viet restaurants in SF that come to mind. Unfortunately, Pho Vietnam on Polk street falls into the latter category.  

But like I said, it has great potential. First off, it's within stumbling distance of my beloved karaoke bar (Encore). Secondly, since its family owned and operated, the service is warm and friendly. Most importantly, it's within stumbling distance of my beloved karaoke bar (Encore). Oh I should tell you, I rate a restaurant's potential by its proximity to my beloved karaoke bar (Encore).

But in all seriousness, THE FOOD HERE SUCKS! BIG TIME! As BIG as Jupiter, as BIG as that tranny's adams apple outside of DIVAS , as BIG as Schwarznegger's tits, ALMOST as BIG as my parking ticket fees...I'm talking BIG TIME, folks. 2 stars.

+1 star --- The owner was helping his daughter with her homework on a laptop when I walked in. I feel like a unbelievable heel for writing such a bad review about a family owned restaurant. Pho Vietnam, Pleasssssse hire a better chef so John T can come back and shower you with more fabulous Yelp stars!
author: John T.

description: No mushrooms in the veggie pho or cream puffs. I have ate far better pho in my life and am not shy to say that this place is not anything special. However, for being a spot in the TL it is normally priced and service is pretty good.
author: Kate D.

description:
I've been craving Pho for a couple months now (there aren't too many pho places around the marina) and finally my friend and I decided to have it before our movie of the night, "Knocked Up."  We were actually looking for a different place but we stumbled upon Pho Vietnam.  Since we were running out of time, we decided to try it.  We ordered the spring rolls and I had the number 10 pho with rare steak and flank steak.  I didn't really like the flank so next time I will order pho with rare steak only.  Unlike other pho restaurants I've been to, they only had one size and it is a really big portion.  They also don't have this pancake appetizer that I've been craving.  (I've only tried it at this place on Larkin and Sutter but that closed down and it is now a Mexican restuarant,).  I don't remember what that place was called, does anyone know if they moved locations?

Anyway, back to my review, I would go back to Pho Vietnam.  The service was great and the food was great!
author: Michelle F.

description:
Pho Diggity!  While coming up with our fabulous plan to spend the rest of our idle Thursday at Adam M.'s pool drinking Pabst 24 cans and smoking, we paused to actually do something healthy for our bodies.  We ate at Pho Vietnam.  Two number 12s with meat on the side and we are slurping away.  The beef balls were a leeeetle suspect but palatable and I'll allow it.  The rare steak was great and I love cooking my own meat.  Tasty broth, plenty of noodles and fixings (aka bean sprouts, jalapenos and cilantro).  Two people, two phos, two waters, less than $20.  
Deal.  Then we grabbed our bathing suits and hit the hot tub.  Ahhhhhh unemployed bliss...I can feel all of you employed Yelpers' hatred.  Like a nice ray of sunshine near the pool.
author: Jill D.

description:
6/10/08
Update: Normally, I don't like to re-visit places I've yelped and only given 3 stars to.  What's the point when there are so many other places to try out?

I was in the neighborhood and super hungry.  I'd actually forgotten that I had eaten here before.  Guess what?  I ordered the exact same thing.  Same review, except that the grilled pork had some pieces that were just inedible fat.  

What I didn't understand was the packed house with a line out the door.  No better lunch options around?  
___________________________
4/17/08
Cheap eats.  Nice staff.  We were a party of 7 and they let one of our party go next door and get something else.  I ordered the bun thit nuong cha gio (grilled pork and egg roll over rice noodles).  The nuoc mam was not good - it was heavy on the fish sauce, no chilies or bright lime flavor.  We were hungry and desperate.  There are better places to get cheap eats in the city.
author: Lynnie P.

description: Pho is just not the same outside Viet Town (aka Tenderloin). This restaurant serves an average bowl of noodle soup at best. I had one with beef tendons which turned out to taste like rubber. It was unchewable and not appetizing. This tells me they don't invest enough time and care into their cooking. My shrimp in the shrimp and garlic noodles did not taste fresh either. Prices are not cheap compared to what typical Vietnamese food cost.
author: Ed L.

description:
Pho is a cure for a wicked hangover, a bad cold, and makes me feel like someone made me chicken soup to cheer me up!   I am not feeling so hot and I am enjoying an exciting night at home with soup and a movie- and yelp.

I love this place because it is a great after yoga dinner and cheap.  I consistently get great soup with white meat chicken- not the nasty, dark,  grizzly parts.  They also have nice spring rolls.

For dessert get a Thai ice tea or go to Lucious Wear next door for power shopping.
author: rachel c.

description: This place was pretty good. I was very happy with my Pho tái, even though this was the most expensive Pho I've ever purchased in the Bay Area, because adding Brisket was an extra $2. The Vietnamese Coffee my friends ordered looked good, and had a cool presentation. Nothing special about decor or location.
author: Melody H.

description:
When I am hungover, I crave Pho and this is 1 of 2 places I go to but I have been coming here for 5 years (After a trip to Vietnam) because it's satisfying and economical.  I stick to basic items on the menu and have not experimented with any other items.

1) Pho Ga (chicken)

2) Spicy round noodles with Beef and Tendon (it's not too spicy but will make your nose run)

3) I can't recall what they call it but either the fresh or fried spring rolls.  They are both yummylicious.  Wrap the fried ones in lettuce, add some vermicelli, and dip in sauce (I prefer to make my own with soy sauce, and the hot chili paste).

And, most times, I order the Vietnamese coffee.  So wicked.
author: Sheila W.

description:
Sure, I've had better pho back in 'Nam, but I've gone to this place so often that their pho itself has become its own entity and my comfort food.  I crave it when its cold, when I'm sick, when I'm tired, stressed...ok, or even just hungry.  When I come here by myself, the servers are nicer and will chat with me.  There's a very grandmotherly little woman there who I LOVE to pieces.  

I always get the pho chay and a pot of green tea.  They don't give me any odd looks when I ask them to leave out the cabbage.  I heart this place.
author: Catherine G.

description:
Don't go here for the Pho. Go here for the #22 which, is actually "beef stew". Probably the best bowl of soup I've had in the city. I always go with the thin rice noodles, but it's offered with silver and egg too. 

Do it.
author: Emily M.

description:
This place has two things going for it for me. 
1.) It's close to my house.
2.) It serves decent Pho. 

I can't say it is the best Pho I have ever tasted but it isn't bad. Although when they serve the Pho with lemon wedges instead of the lime I get a bit sad. The lemon doesn't do it for me like the lime, yah know? It still nips the Pho craving in the bud so it isn't a total loss.
author: Shawn P.

description:
Your basic Tenderloin cheap, quick, pretty good, dirty Vietnamese restaurant except its not dirty and it's not in the tenderloin. For $20 plus tip we got a mixed appetizer plate, an order of stir fired rice with shrimp, beef, and calamari; and a beef noodle soup. All were OK, with the soup broth being the best part. The restaurant is clean and very spacious and service was quick and attentive.  

They were playing a best of the 80's and 90's music mix very slightly more loudly the common in restaurants but I thought it added to the atmosphere in as much as it made any difference. 

Warning: No liquor license yet. 

Three stars seems a bit harsh since it does a good job of being what it is, but I think four is too many so I'll go with three and just say if you are in the neighborhood think about checking it out.
author: Bill S.

description:
I won't lie, you won't see the face of God after trying the pho here.  What really sets Pho Vietnam apart, in my opinion, is the wide breadth of other consistently delicious rice and noodle dishes it offers.  Don't get me wrong, I'll put their pho up against any place on Clement / Irving / further down the TL as it is very very good, but the selection of other excellent dishes is what really wins my heart over  From a yummy catfish over rice to vermicelli with pork and imperial rolls to the most fucking awesome Vietnamese coffee I've ever had, this place does it right.  They also offer an amazing appetizer comprised of rare beef steak, lime, fried onions, and scallions - you have to try it.  

There are big windows you can sit right beside to people-watch on Polk St., and on top of that the service is fast and friendly, the restaurant is clean, and the whole operation is family-owned - what more could you really ask for?  Oh, and it's open until 10pm every night, which is totally crucial on those cold, late nights.
author: Roberto M.

description: Went in here before a movie and ordered pho with a side order of fresh spring rolls. The rolls came out and it looked and smelled like they were sitting out all day. The bean sprouts in the roll were turning brown, the lettuce was wilted and the smell was just too foul for it to be even edible. They told us it was made fresh, but we returned it and comsumed our ordered phos. The pho was on the salty side and glamoured with tons of msg. The meat looked like it was taken straight from the freezer and added to our soups. Still, we were starving and had a movie to catch so we finished most of it and hurried out of there as the waitress smiled her goodbyes with dagger in her eyes. Two stars because we did stay and didnt just walk out from the beginning.
author: HJ P.

description:
On a cold rainy day after a 1.5 hour yoga class, calling in an order of Pho Ga to go and enjoying it at home is the best!  We've never been disappointed with their pho ga or their Spring Rolls.

We're regulars on rainy days.
author: Delilah B.

description:
I'm not sure about the bad reviews, but I have yet to have a bad meal here. One person slammed them for having an "oily broth" - huh? Asian noodle soups always have a bit of lovely, tasty fat floating on the top, if it doesn't, it's neither authentic or good.

  Is it the BEST Vietnamese food ever? No. Is it really damn tasty? Hell yes. I've been to other Vietnamese places in my area by Chinatown and have had vastly inferior versions of various Vietnamese dishes, so I don't understand all the negatives about this place. Maybe there are places out in La Mission that I need to try, but whatever, this is still a great lunch spot.

  No matter which soup you get, the broth is really flavorful and delicious. The pho broth is not a deep brown color (which means they don't use beef base), but still has great depth of flavor. Yeah, the toppings are pretty damn skimpy, particularly when it comes to seafood, but that seems to be the norm in SF, you can't get away from it. The broth has so much flavor that I'll forgive them for being like everyone else in town and getting chintzy with the toppings.

  The spring rolls are also very good. Lately they have had a special grilled pork spring roll that had marinated grilled pork slices, green apple, crispy won ton-like pieces, lettuce, mint and cilantro in it with the obligatory peanut dipping sauce. Was it authentic? Probably not, but it was really damn good.

  Also their Cafe Sau Da is the best I've ever had. I totally jones for it. I keep ordering it at places near where I live and it's just not nearly as deep, rich and flavorful. Worth every penny.
author: Thomas S.

description:
2.5 stars for being clean and well-lit.
.5 for being "good enough"

But unless you are some reason in which you can't take the extra 10 minutes to walk down the hill I recommend just going to Turtle Tower. You can just consider those 10 extra minutes each way calorie points for getting a rich Vietnamese coffee with your pho or bun.
author: Sara K.

description:
The surroundings are pleasant enough, clean, quiet. The staff attentive and the service really fast. The food was fine. There was nothing that stood out as great or not great. It was fine. I was happy to be eating.

There are a lot of other restaurants right there that have reputations, so I figure this place is going to have to try pretty hard to outshine some of them.
author: Marz W.

description:
I took one star off b/c the ambiance is really mediocre.  It's got bare decor with basic tables and chairs that keep you in to eat what you ordered but doesn't really make you want to stick around and stay after.

The food is yummy though.  They serve huge plates and charge very little.  I had the eggplant with tofu in curry sauce, which comes with rice and it was great; it was on their specials menu.  The entree cost me under $10 and the portion size was GINORMOUS, I could easily spread it out into 2 or 3 meals depending on hunger!

Also the service was alright.  It's the level you would expect from a place that has a really affordable menu.

Basically, I would go back for lunch.  For dinner, I'd probably go someplace nicer.
author: Swetha G.

description:
Great thit-nuong and it is within walking distance of our apartment this is why I am a fan. The service was friendly and quick and didn't scare my asian-but-not-vietnamese wife like many of the places in my hometown westminster little saigon. 

I cannot comment on the prices as it is hard for me to comprehend vietnamese food for more than $5, but that is just because I haven't really eaten much vietnamese food outside of little saigon in the late 90's, (lived is largely asian free east san diego for the past 4 years  ) but as our dinner came in under $20 dollars I would have to say that it was cheap enough. Maybe I will find better as I descend further into the T.L. but for now I am fairly happy with this restaurant.
author: David M.

description: Definitely a worthwhile stop. This area in general has great ethnic food and Pho is no different. Numbered menus and a little old Vietnamese lady working hard in the kitchen -- aka the stamp of authenticity.
author: William H L.

description:
Pho Vietnam... Simple and damn good. Now every time I've been here its been nothing but great service and fast! And the portions...umm I don't know where some people have been eating to complain that the portion size is  small??? WTF? Some people must be eating at all you can eat Pho restaurants if they think the portion size is small at this place!?!? 

Anyways... the spring rolls are good, I always get the #11 or is it #13 ?? I'm a creature of habit so I don't stray to far from what I like. And I always end up leaving this place stuffed--on soup! Gotta like that.

Although the one thing that was kinda odd was I was there recently and they had some crazy TV show playing in the kitchen and it had the funny porn music going... Bom chicka wa wa... were they watching porn?? Maybe they were... maybe not!?! Yea good times! Pho and faux porn.
author: Rachael Z.

description: To me a bowl of pho is a bowl of pho.  Hard to differientiate from place to place.  However, these guys were very attentive.  The waitress actually came by twice to ask how my meal was.  That had never happened at a Vietnamese restaurant before!
author: Kristen S.

description:
I've always loved me a big, bad bowl of pho.  And while I've had my share of pho that is phantastic and pho that is phishy, I am happy to report that Pho Vietnam has phreaking phabulous pho.

I've only ever ordered take-out from this place, and the dining room is nothing special, but the staff is friendly, and they always tell you exactly how long it's going to take when you order - and they're always RIGHT about how long it's going to take.  Up-pho-ront honesty.  

There is a beef pho, very simple, that is out of this world.  They provide you the beef raw, cut into thin, evenly sliced slabs.  While you drop those suckers in the super hot broth, you've got a veritable smorgasbord of ways to construct and customize your pho.  Basil?  Yep.  Lime?  Yep.  Sprouts?  Yep.  Delicious, long, cold, phantastically sticky noodles?  Yep.  Cilantro?  Yep.  If you're feeling creative, you can really make a terrific pho, and you can have a good time doing it.  And if you're like me, you'll make yourself a nice mess, too.

There's lots of good little places along this stretch of Polk St, but this one is outstanding when it comes to pho.  Love 'em!
author: Evan G.

description:
Last nite I dined here w/ a friend who ordered Vegetable stir fry $7.95
It had 4 ice cube size fried Tofu's  mixed w/ broccoli, cabbage & some other veg w/ rice. It would have made a nice side order but no way a complete meal, let alone for $7.95.  Pho Vietnam why would you go so skimpy on a Veg Dish???  I had MI Hai San soup, it was just passible & nothing more. I get the sense the place is just a Business with little pride 
in the Cusine it presents.
author: Sparky W.

description:
After a killer bikram class at Funky Door, J and I were in the mood for pho... When we told our server to hold the msg, she informed us that all the soups contained msg. So, we were forced to try other dishes. 

Started with the combination platter (spring roll, imperial rolls, fish cakes). Spring roll very fresh per J, imperial rolls fine but on the 'thin' side compared to other Vietnamese restaurants, fish cakes were a bit soggy...freezer burn? 

J had #26: grilled pork and imperial rolls over vermicelli...it was ok. I had #34 pork shish-kebab with imperial rolls over rice. My pork was delicious...better than the Kal-bi I had the other night at a Korean restaurant! 

So, here's a question for all lovers of Vietnamese cuisine...is it possible to make pho sans msg?

3 stars for food, service and 4 for cleanliness (note: did not visit bathroom).
author: Grace C.

description: Standard, really. The portions are huge, the service was kind of slow, but it also is nice that they aren't rushing or hassling you. Took my friend here for her first try at pho (especially since I was sick and this was the closest place) and she loved it. I got the chicken pho and it was good; she had the beef flank and raved about how smooth the broth was.
author: Shauna S.

description: It's hard to find really authentic and delicious pho here in the city, for WHATEVER reason... this place is pretty tasty.  Bummer it's closed like every time I walk by nowadays...
author: Blake C.

description: I recently moved to the area. With San Francisco's cold weather, a nice big bowl of soup is wonderful and heart warming thing. I have tried so far the steak and the chicken Pho soup and it is great! Big bowl ( which is great for 2 people, or 1 hungry one ) was served very quickly to me.  The flavor was great, the vegetables on the side were  fresh. So if you are looking for a nice , warm dinner under $10 then this is the place!! The interior of the place  is noting fancy, but the central location of the restaurant is convenient to those in the area.
author: Irina V.

description:
Decent Pho close to my house. I prefer Turtle Tower's pho ga but this place does have a wider selection of other foods like stir fries and appies.

I like their shrimp spring rolls and beef pho. I got the curry  stew last time and was not impressed, stick with the pho.
author: Katie M.

description:
Perhaps I have eaten too much Vietnamese food lately,  but I must say I was disappointed with the food here. 

It is close to my work and it is clean, even the service was fast, but I freaked out when I could not figure out what type of chicken I was about the eat. 

I ended up making myself a little sick. I don't think I will come back here.
author: Karen S.

description:
I come here occasionally when I'm in the mood for some hot noodle soup. it's your standard pho place, but about $7-8 per bowl...a little steep in my opinion...unless I've fallen behind on keeping up with inflation :P

Last night I ordered the rare steak and well done flank noodle soup to go. sadly, the soup wasn't hot enough when I got home to cook the rare steak. I microwaved and microwaved until it finally stopped being pink, but then it had a rubbery texture :( I guess my advice is, don't get rare steak to-go.

Also, one small irk - I asked for no onions and no cilantro...because I HATE cilantro, but they left it in :( 

It's the closest pho restaurant to me, so I'll still go back when my pho craving calls!
author: Emily H.

description: I LOVE pho and am new to the neighborhood, so was super excited when I saw a pho restaurant down the street.  The pho is not bad, but definitely nowhere near the best I've ever had.  To tell you the truth I left feeling pretty underwhelmed, but it might just be because this place in my old neighborhood (in LA) had the best pho ever - I would dream about it (unfortunately I doubt I'll be dreaming about this pho).  It'll do the trick when you are craving it, though.
author: Erin L.

description:
Service was much better and the shrimp stirfry with veggies was tasty --- mostly because I love cabbage and that was the main vegetable.

The spring roll (not the imperial roll, but the so-called "fresh" spring roll with shrimp (uh, not so fresh and bland, served with an extra bland peanut sauce --- must add sirracha) still sucks! I would ask the staff and/or chefs -- would you eat this?  I highly doubt it.  DO NOT ORDER THIS.

Still haven't tried the pho, but everyone around me seemed to enjoy theirs.
author: Melissa G.

description: Pretty good pho. Love the coconut drink though!!!!
author: Elizabeth K.

description:
I must confess...I'm not experienced in the finer art of judging Le Cuisine de Vietnam...Pho or otherwise. I am, however, a creature of habit and thought I'd break my repetitive tendencies by trying a restaurant that has been catching my eye with its bright yellow awning for weeks now. 

Oh, Pho, what did I discover about you? Let me count up your tasty ways...

1. Thrifty Tastiness - On special was a chicken curry for the most reasonable price of $6.95. I added deep fried egg rolls of goodness for $1.50. Accompanied by rice and a fresh lemonade, the total dinner bill came to $11.66 (a HUGE bargain by any SF dinner hour standards).

2. New Experience Tastiness - I LOVE curries, but many of them lack a certain depth of spiciness that I usually only find in a handful of Indian eateries. This curry had the consistency of soup, rather than a thick-ish sauce (which was a new phenomenon for me...I KNOW!...sheltered life!) and it was SO GOOD. It was spicy (but not too spicy), with bits of chicken breast nicely seasoned. Went well with rice, as all curries should.

3. Speedy Tastiness - Dinner came quick. Very quick. I could have eaten in 30 minutes flat. Only reading Nabokov slowed me down (who knew Ada would go so well with Pho?).

Too glad was I to expand my comfort zone with a spontaneous dining adventure. I'm a bold Yelper now, ready to go the extra step and suggest an excellent dessert pairing...after Pho, a trip to Bob's for a chocolate donut and milk brings nice closure to an evening out in the Russian hood...my own brand of Fusion cuisine, I think.
author: Julia C.

description:
What the Pho - a much better name for this place.

Like the Quizno's of Vietnamese food. Better than some, but not up there with the best. I do frequent this place, as much as I do or would frequent Vietnamese food, since it's a few blocks from my house and rarely disappointed by my expectations. They will create custom plates for you - like adding a fried egg to the pork chop and rice plate (traditional). Don't recommend going out of your way to come here, but if you are near by and nothing else looks good...
author: Mike C.

description: Vegetarian broth option and fresh coconuts. Enough said.
author: Karan S.

description: I LOVE Pho Vietnam!!  I have never had a bad experience here!!  I always bring my friends to let them in on the awesome!!  My personal fave is the vegitarian Pho with a side of thinly sliced beef strips.  Its amazing, and they don't bat an eyelash when I order this odd mix.  The staff is lovely, the food is the bomb, you can't go wrong with this place!  In fact I'm going to celebrate a special occasion there tonight... cant wait!!
author: Anita O.

description:
I know a lot of people really like this place, but I fear my experience was not so positive however.

I came here with a houseguest for a dinner. I ordered the Pho Tai and while the service was decently quick, I was disappointed by the result. I found the broth to taste like it had come from instant paste, it was about the worst pho broth I have ever had (from sampling pho places across three cities). Combine that with old, diseased looking basil and I was not a huge fan. 

Again a lot of people like it so give it a try, it is perfectly possible that I went on an off night for them, unfortunately I am unlikely to give them another chance with the abundance of other shops just a bit farther from my apartment.
author: Zeke K.

description:
Your legit. pho place--the usual standards

-quick service
-other options for people not into pho
-rather cheap
-satiates that pho craving

the first time i went, i went with friends and the meat legitimately scared me a little but the 2nd and 3rd time I went, the beef wasn't as scary looking.

I always get the brisket/rare steak--EXCELLENT

nothing PHENOMENAL but still just fine--good place to go to get a quick bite--even if it is alone! (many people there doing it as well with a good book, computer, etc)
author: Jung-Ah Y.

description: The Pho here is fabulous!!!   I like to stop by here on my way to my sisters nearby and bring dinner... some restaurants when you get food to go, it just doesnt taste the same at home, but even an hour later everything was delicious !!!  the soup  and the fresh spring rolls are amazing!!!  I can't wait to go back!!!
author: Jessica C.

description: My bf and I come here about once a week because I'm totally obsessed with the pho here. The broth is so yummy, I seriously wake up Saturday mornings craving it. The bbq pork vermicelli noodles are great as well, as are their fried spring rolls. The service is no-nonsense, and its never too crowded. Basically a recipe for a great neighborhood place.
author: Nora G.

description: Only been around for a month and making waves. Good cheap, clean, nearby to my house; pho and 5-spiced chicken were stellar. Vietnamese coffee was strong. Lots of non-Asian customers turned me off to the place, but the food won me over. They need to put the pictures on the wall lower. Needs an Osha-like edge to tip it...
author: Andrew K.

description: I've had pho and some rice dishes here, and while it's not the best I've had, it is more convenient than venturing into the Tenderloin district to get your Vietnamese food fix.
author: Karen W.

description: Brrr...on such a cold day in SF,  the big bowl of Pho I got from Pho Vietnam definitely hit the spot. The place is nothing spectacular but the Pho is pretty quality and cheap which is nice.
author: Debbie C.

description: Spring rolls good.  Lemongrass chicken excellent.  Not a lot of extras, just steamed rice.  Friendly owner and waitresses.
author: Harry F.

description: I think this is a solid neighborhood pho place.  Its near Lumiere, Bob's Donuts and 24 hr Walgreens. I think its a cheap place to meet up, nurse a cold and get your pho' on.
author: Sarah C.

description:
I came here when I sick and got the Pho Ga with chicken and it made me feel 10 times better. Service was fast and friendly I would definitely want to come back here and try the other bowls. The actual venue could maybe look a little nicer, as I felt  I was sitting in a school cafeteria with a few Asian accents, but I suppose that's how fancy you can get with inexpensive Pho.

I would definitely recommend for lunch or a quick dinner, but not if you are looking for a fancy experience.
author: Alex H.

description:
In a search for some good pho, I stumbled in here for lunch one day.  I ordered up the Pho Tai and was excited at the prospect of some good food.  I was so disappointed at the bland broth, even after putting in my normal basil, sprouts, and chili sauce, it needed something else -- yes, flavor! The portions were generous, but does it count when the food is not very good?

So, I decided to give this place another chance.  I had given up on the pho, so I tried the bun -- vermicelli.  I had the grilled pork and imperial rolls over vermicelli.  The flavors were not so bad, but the noodles were way overcooked and were a soggy mess.

Much to my chagrin, I am still on the hunt for some good pho.  I guess I will be venturing into Little Saigon next...
author: Katie M.

description:
What a let down. BF was happy to discover a pho place in my neighborhood. Beats walking down to the tenderloin so we tried it out. We were both seriously underwhelmed by less than generous price per portion ratio and meat that was mostly just little pieces of fat. Not much flavor either.
