Leftovers were so bleh the next day that I tossed them.
Two stars because unless they give me food poisoning, I just can't bring myself to 'one-star' a family business.  Nonetheless, head down towards civic center if you're looking for pho.
author: Megan G.

description: I go to Pho Vietnam after a night if bar hopping or club going. The service can be slow, but who cares when the food is hot and satisfying. It gets kinda cold in there and there are limited seats. I always get the vegetarian pho with tofu. It's delicious when I'm drunk. I have no idea what the food tastes like otherwise.
author: Suzy M.

description:
my favorite pho is in SF- so good.

the best part?! THE SERVICE! i love the employees here! sooo nice.
highly suggest
author: Elliott G.

description: Pho in this one is very good! but the rice plate is just okay....
author: Te Yuan L.

description: I can tell you that #28, 26, and 29, are awesome! I am not sure what they are called but I remember the numbers! The spring rolls done with rice paper were awesome also. I ate there twice in less than 24hrs. I really enjoyed it!
author: Nantas S.

description:
I like this place. I like the huge bowl of broth so all the noodles is submerged and cooks the bean sprouts and herbs without cooling the broth. I wasn't thirsty after the meal, so I think they didn't use too much MSG in the soup.

The decor really needs some work. It's clean and really spare. At least paint the walls with some color and hang some art work.
author: L S.

description:
I always get the vegetarian pho. 

It's great -- fresh bean sprouts, good noodles. It's in my neighborhood and the service is always fast.
author: Janet B.

description:
Been there twice now and while I can't say it's at the top of my "pho-licious" list, it's reliable and consistent.   The small bowl is more than enough and the broth isn't too oily.  Bean sprouts are for the most part fresh and they give you a healthy serving of mint leaves.  

You're not likely to get a smile with service but the 2nd time I was there the waitress was friendly and very talkative.
author: Kenny L.

description:
i moved here from Houston and LA where they had the best vietnamese food in the US, or so says my wonderful vietnamese family.  Needless to say, moving to SF was a major "loss" (of great vietnamese food) for me.  

BUT!  out of all the mediocre vietnamese food places in SF, this is the one i like the most.  The pho broth is very flavorful (which is hard to find since most places in the city have bland broths)!

If you're looking for non-pho, i would recommend "#24 Dry."  it's a southern vietnamese favorite and SOOOO flavorful (although the quail egg ruined it for me).  

I would still go to San Jose if you're looking for great vietnamese food. But if you dont' want to make the drive, give Pho Vietnam another try!
author: J D.

description:
I'm a big fan of pho, and this place has been consistently good over the 5+ times I've been there. Has good portion size, good pricing $6.75 for a bowl.

The broth is really good, and they give lots of meat. The spring rolls are good, and their rice dishes and salads are good as well.

Service is fast and friendly.

Its Photasitc!
author: Eddy N.

description:
Want some noodle soup?

I like coming here to get a good simple bowl of Pho, and it never disappoints.  Unassuming decor and service, this tiny hole on Polk always delivers on the most important aspect of a meal:  good food.  While I've tried some of their rice based dishes, I usually get a bowl of Pho with rare beef and well done flank and sometimes with tendon and tripe.  With this bowl comes sizable serving of the usual side of bean sprouts and mint.  This place is one of my go-to's for a quick good meal, and I've have to tell you that a bowl of Pho for brunch after a big night out soothes both the soul and body.

On a side note, I really appreciate them having both the reusable plastic chop sticks as well as the disposable ones available on the table.  I always prefer the wooden ones (I know, I know; probably not as good for the environment) and many places only have plastic.
author: Lemar H.

description: Its just your regular pho place. Its cold outside and pho just hits ur body right. Now my i am warm and full nuff said
author: Jorm K.

description: I go here almost once a week.  Don't get me wrong - I've given some other places a chance, but when it all boils down to it Pho Vietnam is still my favorite.  Many people think its Pho - you flavor it yourself so who really cares.  Well, oh contrare - it makes a difference.  I get the Pho Ga with 1/2 noodles (I'm always watching my carbs) and its an excellent soup.
author: Daniella S.

description: Attentive and very friendly service. The spring rolls, egg rolls, and pho is delicious! Highly recommended.
author: Matt H.

description: Clean, light, had a couple of vegetarian dishes which were very good.
author: Ken K.

description: Just stopped in for a quick lunch ... i.e., fresh (un-fried) spring rolls. Perhaps it was a bit late for lunch, but the rolls were great: Tough shrimp, bland dips. I did appreciate that they had a "half-order" option, as usually the smallest portion is too big for just myself (for lunch, anyway).
author: T G.

description:
This place rocks. And it's clean. I'm over the nastiness of Tu Lan--watching the cook handle clothing for sale from street people, then go back to cooking w/out washing their hands is too much. (The dog fighting right outside the window got me a little nervous, too.)

So, we had the spicy pork noodle soup and it was absolutely fresh and delicious, w/ all the basil, jalepenos, lemon and sprouts in a bag (we got it to go) to add to it. Also had the Imperial rolls and they were perfect; crispy, w/ fresh noodles and veg on the side.  

So good!
author: Laurian R.

description:
It's times like these that I miss living in the Inner Richmond, a block away from Pho Clement. 

I ordered their Wonton Soup with added vegetables. I am sad that they don't offer thick rice noodles at all- only regular egg or rice noodles. But, I do like that they offer the option of adding steamed vegetables into your pho or soup. 

Even with the hoisin and sirachi sauce, basil, lemon, and sprouts they gave me (standard), it just wasn't as tasty as other Vietnamese soups I've had.
author: Laura D.

description: Gets the job done when you need a pho fix.
author: Joe A.

description: My favorite Pho in the city. Plus the family is super nice that owns this place. Everything else is good as well, but if you go here, go for the Pho.
author: Jordan P.

description:
This is my local Vietnamese restaurant in San Francisco. I guess that means I can count myself as fairly fortunate. The food here is fantastic. Any of the Pho or rice dishes are great, but my favorite is a raw beef appetizer soaked and cooked in citrus juices ( I think it's called Bo Tai Kanh (sp?)).

The service isn't always great, but it's improved since they seem to notice me as a regular. Other than that, the food is great and comes highly recommended.
author: Kyle C.

description: variety to spring roll creations in a positive twist...something crispy inner...something soft outer...pork spring roll?...excellent change from traditional shrimp...finding pho grand and large...trying something different...getting spicy noodle soup...fatter noodle...tongue numbing spicy oil...broth slight oily, but acceptable...only note meat slicing obviously cooked and sliced seperate tasting bit off..not knowing reasoning...continue noodle soup dining....biggest fault being "very increased pricing" experience...quite the hefty fee for soup and rolls....
author: Hen A.

description: This place is very close to my house, but after eating here several times, I am unwilling to give it another chance. Which is a shame since it's so close. I just thought the pho was pretty gross (and I like authentic pho) this pho just seems off. I ordered a noodle dish once that was pure onion, which is just disgusting. Also, after reading other reviews about cockroaches and glass in the food, by principle I could never return.
author: jen w.

description:
I only order pho or five spice chicken.  I've tried a few of their other dishes and they're forgettable.  Two people can share the pho and be full.  This place is cheap and dirty.  Don't let the seemingly clean exterior fool you.  Cockroaches abound.

The rare beef pho is good.  The chicken noodle soup is an ideal meal when you're sick.  Try it the next time you get the bird or booze flu.
author: Scott W.

description:
I loved it. This was my first pho experience, EVER, and i was pretty dang excited. I got the veggie pho, and with a more educated friend to guide my hand with the chili and basil and other traditional condiments, i was all set.

It was fairly cheap for a massive bowl. I had enough left over for two meals!

the service was pretty good, the waitress offered to take our picture when she saw us struggling to all fit.

mmm.
author: Rebecca M.

description:
This place is great for pho and spring rolls! Prompt service. For dessert try the tri-color drink...it's super-yummy! 

The only thing that's a bit strange are the restrooms which are located down a hallway that gets kind of dark at the end. When you open the door it's totally dark in there and you don't know where the light switch is. 

Overall however, this place has great food. No frills authentic Vietnamese on Polk Street. Hooray com'pho'rt food! ;)
author: A G.

description:
NOTE: Rating based solely on the Pho.

I'd seen this place on my walk to yoga and was curious. I'd only had pho maybe 3 times total before, all at different places and it's only about 3 blocks from home. Finally tried it out for a Friday night dinner and movie with the bf.

I hadn't yelped the place, and I was a little skeptical at first as when we headed over (between 7 & 8 Friday night) as there was only 1 table occupied when we got there, but we took a seat anyway. We both ordered the Pho Thai, and I enjoyed it! It came out EXTREMELY hot, but was very tasty and was between $6 & $7 for a huge bowl. We also ordered Thai iced teas. They weren't as sweet as I was used too, but still good as well. The plate of mint, sprouts and jalapeños was good for the two of us (especially as we only care about the sprouts anyway).
author: M R.

description: People still talk about Tulan on 6th street because they got that review from Julia Child in the 70's.  But this place on Polk is my 4-star greasy home-cookin' destination for Vietnamese.  My favorite is dry vermicelli (bun) and they make it in the style of 2 different cities.  Enjoy it with the Vietnamese version of Thai ice tea, which is much stronger and sweeter.   The wet soups are on par with the rest, but don't miss the egg rolls (Cha Gio). They're compact, and loaded with roasted garlic and caramelized onions.
author: randal S.

description:
Crusing around Japantown and craving some Japanese ramen, but opted for Pho. Should have went for the ramen.

Got the #7 which is the large Pho with everything. $8.95, which is expensive for Pho.

The lady came out with a couple HUGE bowls. I was like damn :D ..then I peered into the soup to see a laughable amount of meat and noodle :(. Wow.. I must be paying her extra for carrying out these oversized pointless bowls instead of the actual content.

The soup base was really bland and lacked any real flavor. Skimping on the msg too? haha jk.  I had to drown the base with Sririacha and Hoisen sauce for a more enjoyable soup.

In conclusion, I have had way better Pho than what was served to me today.
author: Simon S.

description:
Can you say MSG?
Im not sure what MSG smells like until I walked into this  restaurant seriously.

Can I get a small pho ga  and a gallon of water with that please?
-This place is not worth going unless you are near and in need of pho. -Vegetarian springs rolls where not good nor wrapped well.
-The bean sprouts were brown and tasted rotten. So gross and the ends looked like strands of thin hairs coming out of it. Swallowing the bean sprouts felt like it was tickling my throat. 
- Not worth the money and its $$$ for pho.

At the end of my meal and throughout the day, I needed a lot of aqua.

I will never come back.
author: K L.

description: Somebody in this restaurant needs to learn how to pluck and clean a chicken! I have leftovers, this rarely happens! On top of it, it's pricier than the huge delicious chicken dinner at cordon blue around the corner.
author: Sarah L.

description:
The first time I ever experienced the love that is pho, I was living in Seattle and one of my best girlfriends took me to Than Bro's. As soon as my complimentary mini cream puff arrived (before the pho, no less!), I knew I had been shot with Cupid's arrow. 

It's been about 5 years since I left Seattle and have been searching for pho that lives up to the Than Bro's legacy. Pho Vietnam ALMOST makes the cut. Of course, there are no pre-pho cream puffs...but the noodle goodness itself definitely hits the spot. I had the pho ga and am happy to the report that the broth had the perfect balance of flavors i've come to expect from amazing pho and the chicken seemed fresh, tender and tasty. While I could have used some more bean sprouts, the veggies and garnishes were on point. Like some other Yelpers, I found the lemon wedge (instead of the usual lime wedge) a bit odd. Overall, I left full and satisfied with my sinuses completely clear! I'll definitely be back.
author: Chris S.

description:
Polk Street --- It twitches me out a bit, a strange borderland between creepy rich and creepy poor.  Tonight I saw a cabbie ding the rear of a vintage jag as he zipped out of a bus stop.   A tiny, wiry junkie shouted "Damn did you see him hit that jag!" I says "sure did."  This other guy in the crosswalk wearing a nice yachtsman style windbreaker and with fluffy white hair grumbles "That jag isn't hurtin' --- ha."

Tonight I also had a bowl of bun on Polk.  It was a good bowl, but like all bun  it had its peculiarities.  The substandard bits were the imperial rolls (a $3 add-on to the BBQ beef bun).  The rolls were tiny, thumb size, which was cute, but I felt like I was eating lumpia.  I also only got two of the little tings, and perhaps because of there size they tasted of little more than fried dough.

The excellent parts of this bun, and why this place deserves the 4 stars, was the beef.  It had a lovely grilled quality and (like most Vietnamese places) was nice quality with good beef flavor.  There was also a spice rub involved.  Other points in favor of this bun were the fine garnishes --- deep-fried onion bits! --- and plenty of salady goodness in the bottom of the bowl.
author: Gustie L.

description:
Finally decided to try this place that's just around the corner from me.
Tried the # 13 - chicken pho. It was decent.
Not as good as Turtle Tower as their Chicken Pho is phontastic.
Recommend it if you feel like Pho and don't want to walk down to TT or travel to your favorite Pho place.
author: Tyler B.

description: Had a big bowl of Pho. Good and cheap!
author: Joshua S.

description: Don't be fooled by Pho Vietnam's exterior (or interior for that matter). Under this casual and slightly boring decor is delicious broth and tender meat. The Pho Thai (my go to dish) comes with thinly sliced meat (I order on the side and cook in the broth), basil, lemon, and fresh bean sprouts. I always leave with half a bowl left, full to the brim. The only down side is that you might get hungry again a couple hours later. Also try the fresh spring rolls in my favorite peanut sauce. For roughly $15 a person (with drink) this is my go to place!
author: Natalie N.

description: More like 2.5 stars.  It's a no-frills pho place with average everything.  Good for a bite if you're in the area, but there are better pho places not too far away.
author: Carlin E.

description:
I'm not an expert on Vietnamese food.  Though i've eaten it plenty of times before, i won't tell you that the pho is authentic or the vermicelli is cooked to perfection.  As far as i can tell, it's cheap, satisfying Vietnamese fare.  That alone makes it deserving of four stars.

So why the five stars?  I'm glad you asked.  

Three words: "Spicy Lemongrass Fish." 

Three more words: go try it.  

(I know it doesn't sound like much, but do yourself this favor and try it with your mouth.  (If the fish freaks you out then opt for the chicken.))
author: Ben S.

description: Great food and great service!  I love this place!  The staff is so friendly - they always remember who I come in with and ask about them the next time I come - whether it's my sister, significant other or a friend.  The food is delicious - I always get the pho ga or the bo lac bac.  Both are really  good!  The vegetarian spring rolls are also yummy.
author: Priti M.

description: The bun bo hue is my favorite dish here (and plum soda drink)!  Fast and friendly service.  Nice family-owned restaurant.  :)
author: C Đ.

description: This restaurant is great!  The service is fast, food is good, and price is fairly inexpensive.  It has the best pho out of the few Vietnamese restaurants in SF.  For those of you who like pho with the steak, ask for them to put steak on the side.  Do this nomatter which restaurant you eat at, the meat will be nice and tender.  No one needs overcooked steak.  If you like the steak still slightly pink, put in the vegetables and hoisin/sriracha sauce and the meat last.  I'm a pain in the ass nomatter where I go, but they've always done things right for me.  Go try it!  Btw, pho is a great hangover cure for you alcholics!  I just have one complaint...why the hell won't they deliver?!  I crave for pho quite often, and they're not making it convenient for me to enjoy their pho!
author: My Loan J.

description:
I love this place, I found it right after they opened a couple years ago. I go there often. The service it great, the lady that always serves me is super sweet, and the food is terrific.
I took a very good Vietnamese friend that and he even said it was great and authentic. 
and it beats the pants off the Bodega Bistro down on Larkin.. But that isn't really saying much.
author: Stan P.

description:
Although I'm giving it 5 stars, it doesn't mean it's a 5-star restaurant. But for what they're aiming for, Pho Vietnam definitely hits its mark.

If you want to find a place where you can get good, yummy, quality authentic Vietnamese food, for under $10, this is the place. Plus, add to it that it's in a pretty well-lit, part of Polk that's safe to walk to, then it's another added bonus. I appreciate the places in Little Saigon, but really don't want to risk driving my car there, or having to cab it for a quick bowl of pho. 

The ladies who serve you are super-nice and attentive, and food is consistently good and flavorful. It's definitely kept to its Vietnamese roots (this is coming from a Viet Ku girl herself). It's my own version of home cooking when I'm feeling a bit homesick. Don't expect much ambiance, but if you want a great, quick, filling Vietnamese meal, this is the place to go.
author: Nora D.

description:
my boyfriend and i stumbled into this place while waiting for a movie at the lumiere theater. i was pleasantly surprised. my pho was pretty delicious and the place was very clean. the noodles my boyfriend ordered was quite good as well. the only thing was that the rolls that came with his dish were dinky.
the service was fast and friendly.
this will definitely become my neighborhood pho spot.
author: Michelle K.

description: So so so good.  Spot on, this is the best pho.  I'm rarely in this neighborhood but I like to go here when I am.  It's one of my favorite pho places and I eat a lot of pho.  I haven't had anything else here, just pho.  Great place and it's not too spendy.
author: Emily T.

description: I still can't pronounce 'pho' but I had some of it from Pho Vietnam recently and while it wasn't great it was a satisfying lunch. I did enjoy the 'choose your own adventure' style of takeout-my $7.00 order of pho came in three different containers and I was able to construct the my ideal bowl of noodles-extra basil and bean sprouts please!
author: phil h.

description: This place is relatively cheap and gets the job done. Pho comes in around $8. I also really like the fresh spring rolls.  For pho, I kept it simple and ordered the pho with tender beef.  Add a little sriracha and some plum sauce and it was just what I hoped for.  Little to no ambiance, but quick service, clean enough and worth the money.
author: Gary C.

description:
place sucks.. lady always take my order (pho w/ no onions, no cilantro), repeats the order then comes back and the food has onions and cilantro! ppl need to write things down if they're not gonna remember anything! i never go there anymore..

sadness!
author: Jenn D.

description: Coming here was my first "real" experience with Vietnamese food.  I've been to Slanted Door and had some Vietnamese foods here and there, but I've never had the Pho.  So I found myself here with a friend on a Wednesday night before heading off to a movie.  We ordered the spring rolls as an appetizer and they were delic.  Reminded me of Thai food with the diaphanous wrapping and peanut sauce.  I also ordered the number 10, which was the rare steak and flank steak.  I added basil, Sriracha sauce, jalapenos, and bean sprouts.  Everything was pretty tasty.  I only ate about half of my soup though because portions are quite large.  I also saw a tranny here which made my night.  I'd surely come back.
author: Vanessa Z.

description: My friend and I used to go to this place if we got the graving for Vietnamese food until I found bugs in my pho. I wasn't that upset at first because I figured they maybe just didn't wash the vegetables as well as they should have. I did get upset when the guy tried to tell me that the multiple things in my soup and on my napkin were not bugs even though they obviously had legs. People around us confirmed they were too so not sure why he keep making excuses. He went from arguing with me that they were broccoli to some other weird thing I had never heard of. Anyway I think it is a given that I will not be going to this restaurant ever again.
author: Marian F.

description: Can't say there was anything too memorable about my visit here, the pho tasted all right, they have the usual "all-the-meat" combo here as well which comes in a bigger bowl than the rest of the bowls but I felt like it was lacking on the meats side. Maybe cause it was in that bigger bowl? They do a good thai ice tea as well so props for that. I give it a 3.5 but I have to round down just because there was nothing super remarkable about my visit. It's not a bad place to get a bowl of pho by any means though.
author: Roland C.

description: I had my hopes up from a recommendation, and it looked okay, but the pho here was really disappointing.  It's relatively expensive for pho, and especially when you consider that the food isn't very good.  The plate of veggie fixings is just sad.  The noodles in the pho had obviously been sitting out to dry for a while because they took a while to soften up.  The meat was just kinda gross.  The broth was bad.  Just disappointing in general.
author: Jon N.

description: 3.5 stars. They finally started to turn off that horrible overhead fluorescent lighting. I only tried  different versions of pho here. Good broth, good meats. Sometimes noodles were too soft for my taste. Very clean place and the staff is friendly.
author: Zhanna K.

description: I've been to several Vietnamese places... I like Tu Lan.
author: Jason R.

description: In my opinion, the best Vietnamese food in SF. Pho is fantastic, pork chops are divine, and Guo Coun (not sure about spelling but it's the clear wrapper rolls) are tasty. Service is great and the restrooms are fairly clean.
author: Earl Y.

description: Pho is tasty and the 5th star is for being open before 11am on a weekend.  It's difficult enough to find decent pho in this city, let alone a place to eat it for brunch.  Pho Vietnam get it right!  Plus who can hate on all the "3 Sisters" paintings, quick service and price?  Skip all the trendy places for brunch and treat yourself to giant bowl of pho from here, then spend the rest of your day wandering up Polk checking out all the stores along the way.  perfect lazy Sunday!
author: shawn g.

description: Came here trying to venture off some where else rather than little saigon on larkin. The place is bigger than most and seats a good amount. Theres a was about 3 tables already dining in after we came in so we expected service to be on point. I already knew what I wanted but I like to browse through the menu and see whats special about this place and the variety they offer. Nothing too out of the ordinary but its a good selection for what it is. The service was a little slow and it took some time to get someones attention. They didn't seem so friendly with us and just kinda took our order and forgot about us. Food took about 10min, all in minutes after each other. Which was questionable because we all order the same thing. Im not usually one to complain but most places have a big old cauldron of soup boiling back there so pho is usually up in a minute or so. The pho was not bad, but not the best that'll have me coming back for more. The broth was a little light than flavorful, there was a good amount of noodles but there was hardly any meat. Of course I ate it all but I've had better pho other places and nothing compares to some San Jose pho! After finishing, they cleared the table and I told the waitress we were done. We waited again, thinking they would come back with the check but we had to flag them down for it. Upon receiving the check the guy stood at the table waiting for us to pay. Have a little courteously and let us figure out our money without someone starring at us uncomfortably. I know asian restaurants are not best on service but I know they got some common sense. I think I'll just settle for Little Saigon next time.
author: Christopher P.

description: This place is definitely a frequent haunt for me.  Open late, good Pho and tasty specials from time to time.  I love "Fresh" young coconut juice- not the can stuff that is served full of unnecessary cane sugar, well this place serves it fresh and in the coconut!  I go here just for this tasty/healthy treat.  I am bummed that they don't serve one of my favorite dishes bun rieu (Crab Meat Noodle Soup) but the broth in both their Chicken and beef Pho is tasty enough that it brings me back again and again.
author: Alicia W.

description: I'm from San Jose where there are many Pho places to choose from.  I've been to Turtle Tower in the Tenderloin and though I like it, it's northern style and doesn't give me the same comfort I get with skinnier dense noodles.  Thank goodness for Pho Vietnam.  Their pho has the right proportion of noodle (bun)  to broth and the noodles are not all stuck together.  The broth is clean tasting and not too oily.  I finally have a solid pho spot in the city when I get my craving which is often.
author: Michele H.

description: Sweet! - a great pho & bun place that doesn't require me to walk all the way into the sketchy tenderloin. My vietnamese staples - pho & bun are both done quite well here. I usually also order a vietnamese lemonade too. This place is very clean (almost too sterile) and bright. A great addition for the Polk 'gulch'.
author: Neil K.

description: I feared the worst. Why? Because this place is clean and in a nice part of Polk St. Could a place like this make good Vietnamese food? Yes, actually, they can.  My pho tai came in a bowl bigger than my head, and I finished ALL of it.  My noodles were a bit soft, but otherwise, this dish hit the spot for $5.95. Best of all, no need to hit the TL or Chinatown anymore for a pho fix.
author: M A N I K.

description: this place is disgusting. chicken does not have hair on it! the server said that the chicken comes with hair on it and that it wasn't their fault ("it's chicken hair, not people hair") I would prefer human hair to chicken hair!   we will NEVER ever go back to this place again. stay away, there are much better places to go!
author: Holly H.

description: Cheap eats.  Fairly tasty.  Nothing to write home about, but it won't make you sick.
author: darla s.

description: Pretty good, not as good as what you can get on Clement but serviceable. Way better and way cheaper than Aux Delices up the street. Probably the second best pho I've had in the city (after Pho Hoa on Clement) Their egg rolls are smaller than the ones you usually get in a vietnamese restaurant. They're more cocktail sized. But still tasty.
author: Cathy T.

description: Nothing special.  In terms of food, this place is OK, but we had a bad experience.  My friend asked for the meat in her soup to come on the side.  When we got the bill, they charged her for putting it on the side and said that due to how little meat they normally put it, it didn't look right on the plate, so they added extra meat and thus charged her.  Whether you want to dislike them for being so chincey on the meat, or for being so petty as to charge her without asking.... just left a bad taste in our mouth about the place.
author: Jared F.

description: I was looking for pho near my apartment without having to walk all the way down to 'Little Saigon' and Vietnam II, the place I am used to going to. Well, this is close by and QUICK -- I ordered and had my pho within 5 minutes! Once I walked the 5 blocks home it was still hot enough to cook the rare beef, and I had a new place for pho!
author: Darren M.

description: I haven't had pho in over a year mostly because I've heard the p ho in this city is just not that good.  And also I had a traumatic experience at pot de pho on geary an djust never dared tried it again.  This place was a nice surprise for a casual sunday brisk evening.  I had my tradition tendon w/ rare steak.  Tons of meat and noodles, way too much food.  I think I had way too much soup because I got up to use the bathroom 3 times that night.  Vietnamese coffee also had me rolling around my bed unable to sleep for 2 hours.  I will definitely be going back for the cheap foodies.
author: Tiffany L.

description: My friends like this restaurant a lot. They took me to try it last Sunday morning and it was good. I will give this place a 3 Stars if I can. We got the Combination Beef Noodle soup. Indeed, it turned out a lot better than I expected. Definitely, better than many Viet restaurants in SF! The Broth tasted very good though I wish they gave us more veggies. Service is slow. The husband and wife, also owner I think, run the whole place themselves. They need to hire more people to run the place! I felt the place is clean unlike most Viet restaurants if you know what I mean. My friend even told them not to lower the quality of the soup or we would not return! haha
author: Joe C.

description: Good food, price is very reasonable and portions are generous. The restaurant is also very clean. I especially like the egg rolls and the 5-spiced chicken is a must try. One of the better Vietnamese restaurant in the area.
author: L K.

description:
Everyone has an occasion for grubbing on a big bowl of pho. Popular reasons/ excuses I can think of off the top of my head: illness, hangovers, lack of funds, super duper hunger, cold weather, sore throats, dental issues, exposing a wimp to something new/ familiar. So yeah, hooray for pho in general. 

I'm erring for 4 stars because although it's a solid three and a half establishment, turns out its a popular establishment for solo diners therefore I can justify the extra half star. I came here at around 8 o'clock on a Saturday and at least half the occupied tables were taken up by parties of one (myself included) dining on big bowls of pho. 

Speaking of the pho, it was above par but not as inexpensive as plenty of other similar establishments throughout the entire Bay Area. The menu offers a nice selection of pho, including a vegetarian pho that's serving size is larger than most fishbowls I've owned and basic broth and noodles, which I'm sure could come in handy on a horrific first post flu day. I got a #13, which had a healthy amount of a steak throughout it. The noodles needed a healthy spear chucking session (yet another feeble attempt at using chopsticks) to be separated before consumption. Actually I'm glad I was by myself because after adding all the sprouts, chili, pepper, lemon (no lime) and salt to my heart's desire, my bowl looked like a mini operating table with chopsticks, a fork and drowning spoon as my clumsy instruments of terror. The portion size was good for the quality of the ingredients but not as big as some small servings in the South Bay. Still, it was nice to leave the establishment contently full instead of  "oh geez, I'm going pop" bloated. I did take a peek at several other tables orders of the popular imperial rolls and made a mental note to come back and try them.

The interior is modest but bright and clean inside. The service is quick and I don't think I saw a single table wait more than ten minutes for food to start coming out. I had a couple of members of the waitstaff ask if I liked my meal so that was a nice touch to my filing meal. The location is really convenient to a lot of Polk Street distractions so I can see myself stopping by pre and post hangover and even on those no hangover forecast in sight days. Worth my time and my money.
author: Veronica G.

description: Vietnamese food is probably my second favorite food (after Japanese food.)  And this place was pretty good.  I tried the Pho Tai, my usual. The soup was very flavorful and the noodles, just the right consistency.  Service was fast and friendly, although they forgot my water initially.  It's in a convenient and comfortable location and feels very clean.  I'll be back to try the bun bo (rice noodle salad dish)  That will be the true test... stay tuned!!
author: Haru K.

description: Love this place! It is a regular place for me to meet my parents and siblings for lunch. The service is fast and the food is always good. Imperial rolls are good and the pho is tasty. The decor is the usual no-frills, which is fine by me. I've been to plenty of pho places in the Tenderloin, Sunset and Richmond districts and this one ranks up there as one of my favorites.
author: Amy H.

description: I just got back from Vietnam and I have to say that this was as good or better than 90% of the food I ate in Vietnam.  I can't believe that I live 3 blocks away and have never tried this restaurant until today!  I had the Bun Cha Something-er-other (vermicelli noodles with pork) and it was fantastic.  the coffee is really strong and has a nice flavor.  My wife had the Pho Ga (chicken pho) which was absolutely spot on.  The only reason I can't give 5 stars is because it was a little more expensive than I expected for Vietnamese food, still only around $25 for lunch for two people.
author: Charles W.

description: I'm actually addicted to the #47 (vegetarian pho)  I get it twice a week!  The veggies are always fresh and the tofu is firm.   LOVE THIS STUFF!
author: Sarah F.

description: Ordered the Pho and it cleared my hungover head and was pretty tasty.  The service was good.  I'll be back with an update after my next trip.
author: Peter H.

description:
good stuff.
convenient location, clean (if not boring), well presented (non-plastic bowls, non-chipped tableware), and tasty, vietnamese food.
author: shaun l.

description: I crave Vietnamese food at least once a week, so this is where I go when I'm craving for spring rolls, pho, or cold noodles during lunch. I work only a few blocks away from here, so I come here a lot. The spring rolls are delicious. The perfect portion of shrimp, lettuce, and rice noodles. Peanut sauce is smooth and creamy. You can't go wrong with the beef pho or cold noodles either.
author: Denise L.

description:
well, i suppose i got what Joshua P. had in mind in terms of authentic.

cockroach in food.  and i'm vegetarian.

nuff said.
author: Lindsay D.

description:
I go to Pho Vietnam on a somewhat frequent basis. And despite my disappointment in their constant level of mediocrity, I find myself going there again and again. 

I simply cannot get enough Vietnamese food. The combination of fresh ingredients and strong lemongrass flavors is too tempting to resist. But when I go to Pho VIetnam, what I get is anything but salivating. I normally order the Tofu Bunh. At most other Vietnamese restaurants, you can expect the tofu to be lightly sauteed in a lemongrass sauce. Not at Pho. The plop together some veggies and noodles, fry the hell out of some crusty old tofu, plunk it down in front of you and expect you to be happy with it.

I've tried to circumvent the flavor issue by asking them to season the tofu with lemongrass, and what I get is an sopping*blop* of sopping sauce, tofu and noodles. Worst of all, they charge me $10 for this monstrosity every time!

Next time I'm craving Vietnamese, I'll take the risk and just head down to the tenderloin.

* Essentially, if my food were to fall off the plate, it would make this noise*
author: Celina Z.

description:
we're always on the look out for a good bowl of pho.  we usually default for the pho joint on irving by 19th ave.  we call this place affectionally "fee fi pho"... ha ha, get it?  ;-P

one saturday while looking for some eats after a matinee by amc 1000, we strolled by and saw this place on polk st.  wasn't crowded, nor empty. we threw caution to the wind and decided to give it a whirl.

menu had many of the recognizable dishes one would find in a pho noodle joint and we decided to get our 2 standards to base our first trials on.  we got a bowl of pho with the rare beef and a bbq pork "buhn" (sp?) noodle dish.

both were very tasty.  before i could get my digicam set up to shoot the dishes, my food pal had already devoured a good percentage of the bun plate...Doh!  she looked like she was def enjoying it.

i started in on my pho bowl and was very pleased.  b4 the pho arrived, they brought a good supply of fresh basil, sprouts, jalapenos, and 2 slices of lemon.  all the necessary pho accouterments which make the experience the way it should be.

some places serve their pho not as hot as it should be.  on a cool/cold SF day or nite, nice HOT bowl of pho is one of those things to look forward to.  the pho in this place met that requirement and then some with the quality of the meal itself.  service was swift, pleasant, and the glass of soda pop that i ordered with our meal was generous.

next time we're in this neighborhood and looking for pho or other VN noodle dishes to try, pho VN is on the top of our list.

good eats. :-P
author: Patrick M.

description:
warning............ warning and warning...............do ot go eat this place. I have been to this place more than a year and order the togo ( pick up many times) finally yesterday I ordered 2 noodle soups.

when I open and put them in my bowl I saw a big cockroach inside the noodle. very disgusting......!!!

I called the restaurant and spoke to the owner, she told me to bring the soup back and they wth ill make a new soup for me..

ARE YOU F***ING KIDDING???????? The reason that I called for complaint not for a f***ing new soup. It for the owner to make sure that no more this issue happen to another customers.

Thanks for offer me a new soup but I wont go back to this restaurant ever again..

DISGUSTING!!!!
author: Grace C.

description: The Pho Tai is cheap, HUGE, and is fresh and tasty.  The decor could use some work (I don't think it's helping the very sweet owners attract customers - especially at night when the fluorescents are in full swing).  Overall, though - great Pho if you're down for a cheap quick bowl in the Polk Gulch.  One drawback is that I don't think they serve alcohol of any kind.
author: Jes H.

description: The fact that no one was in there should have given me a huge clue that this place was not very good, but I wanted to be positive because some of the best food finds are "hole in the walls". After receiving my dish my face fell. I got the vermicelli dish with chicken and it was awful. The chicken was dark meat that was tough and difficult to eat, the noodles were over done, and it was tasteless.  Not happy, not happy at all.
author: Kat F.

description: Pretty good pho place for hangover cure and cold rainy days.  Parking around this area could be a pain on busy days though.   My favorite is #7 with a red bean drink.  Try the imperial rolls if you are super hungry!
author: Jeff H.

description: we were craving something warm when we happened to find this place on a very cold winter day. i ordered #10 and he ordered #12. we were the only people there the majority of the time and service was pretty quick. pho was good but a bit too salty. still not as good as tay giang or as cheap...$7.25 a bowl. i'd  be back if i were in the area again.
author: Helen L.

description: I would say 4.5 on this one.  The pho was excellent.  I ordered one with shrimp, lobster claw, and crab; my husband had the beef - both yummy.  The portions are huge and they have a lot of menu items to choose from; it's more like three meals than one.  The prices aren't bad either.  The service was friendly and fast.  I will definitely be back to try more!
author: Rise G.

description: Okay, so I didn't try the Pho.  The only place I've ever liked it is Vietnam, so after reading all the reviews about bad vietnamese food in San Francisco I thought I should go with my favorite and have the bun.  It was delicious and filling.  The ingrediants were fresh and it was served by the cutest, kindest old lady.  The noodles verged on over done, which is the reason for the three stars, but when I go back and try the pho, it could very well change to four stars.   Try the cafe sua da.  Delicious.
author: lauralee s.

description: I delayed trying this place for some time, and apparently with reason.  The service was terrible, bordering on offensive.  Tasty enough but I would only go back again for take-away and even then, I'm not sure I would patronize this establishment.
author: Lady Ms. K.

description: So since this is the only pho place around the Polk area (that I'm aware of), me and my boyfriend have been coming here whenever we're in the mood for pho. However, this past time, I had a dead bug in my basil... That is NOT cool, I'm not coming back again, thank you. That is just unforgivable.
author: Richard C.

description: Have you ever felt like someone was watching you.  Watching your every bite, your every sip of water and then some.  Well, this is the place.  Expect a little old lady with dark frame glasses here.  With her hands behind her back, pacing back and forth from one side of the room to the other.  Walking by your table, scoping out how much you've eaten, whether you're water glass in empty, and her facial espression is always serious and perhaps in concentration mode.  Who knows, but she did creep me out a bit.  However, because she was so attentive, we had good service of course.  So the food. . . . Vietnamese food is always reliable.  I had the vermicelli salad with egg rolls and grilled pork.  Its your typical, but interesting thing is.  It had the best noodles.  Not overly cooked or any thing.  It was just "perfect" texture, and I never had noodles like that, believe it or not.  My friends had the seafood pho and lets just say we all consumed our dish completely.  I think we just inhaled and it all disappeared.  Ah, sweet cheap Saturday early dinner.  Its cool, but its pho yo. . . .can get it any where, so I would say this place is okay.  Nice, good food, but just a lady hawk there, that's all.
author: Janice F.

description: this is the closest pho place to me so i decided to check it out when i was craving a bowl of hot noodle deliciousness.  very disappointment with the pho.  noodles were overcooked and meats were scarce.
author: Helen T.

description:
great cheap-o place to get your grub on and still have room to dish some more goodies in your mouth (stop laughing cuz you got a dirty mind!)

fish cakes and the egg rolls are fantastic faves. get a large bowl of pho tai and it's just bliss.

well go nuts, order a bunch of stuff and share it with friends cuz it's a great, casual place without the fuss and fluff that soo many sf joints like to hype up.

this is were the real foodies come to dine!
author: K K.

description: Came here with a friend after the BDB sale and it was probably the worst Vietnamese place I've ever tried.  I had the vermicelli with imperial rolls and pork. the vermicelli was warm and soft (did not feel right on the palate).  While still cheap, it was more expensive than my favorites Golden Star (Walter Lum St in Chinatown) and PPQs in the Sunset.
author: Dbear T.

description: This is my go-to place for pho! I am addicted to their food, the staff is very neighborhood friendly, and everything is consistent.  I eat here about once a week (have only ordered the chicken pho) and crave it probably more.  The pho on the streets of Vietnam was good and this makes me feel pretty darn close to it.
author: J N.

description: Not giving them 5 stars because last time I went the meat wasn't as good as usual, but it's regularly great!!! I usually only get the regular pho with rare steak and the fresh spring rolls which are AMAZING!!! So that is the only thing I can speak of. good if you just wanna pick up they give you plenty of sriratchi sauce and the other brown sauce. The bean sprouts are always fresh.
author: Cynthia M.

description:
I just realized that Pho Vietnam is a restaurant name redundancy.  Why not just Pho or just Vietnam?  What else could go with Pho?  Pho Outback!  Pho Burger King!  But this is good Pho and lots of it at a great price.  Perfect for a cold SF day or night.  Also good are the grilled dishes--I recommend the grilled pork strips on vermicelli.  The grilled dishes come on a bed of lettuce and tiny cucumber bits with grated carrots on the side.  I know it sounds weird but try it.  I also like the big bowls of steamed rice that they give you for $1.

And unlike lots of Vietnamese restaurants in this low price range, this place is clean clean.  I like that--I've had enough stomach pains and toilet runs from down-and-dirty places to last my lifetime.

So try Pho Vietnam.  Why not Vietnam Pho?  Ho Ho Ho Ho Ho Ho Ho Ho........Chi Minh.  They beat our ass but they sure brought good food over here.
author: Murray S.

description: Pho Vietnam sucks.  This is one of the worst pho experiences I've had and I've eaten a lot of pho.  The pho is watery, the beef is dry and chewy, the waitresses are sullen and it just sucks.
author: melissa r.

description: If you love pho, then I have to inform you that this place is weak sauce. When you crave pho, especially when you're having the worst hangover of your life, you want the pho to be done just right.  Maybe they need to drive to Costco more often to get fresh meat, but I get the feeling that they won't wanna try.
author: Johnny Y.

description: This is super tasty.  I went there with my brothers girlfriend, who is Vietnamese, also said that it was great and true to the traditional style.
author: Justin J.

description:
At different times I have had sour (vinegar?) pho, okay pho, and then gas-inducing pho the last time.  

No matter if it's hot or or freezing, they usually have at least one of the huge windows open, which can make you and your hot food cold.  Must be because they don't have adequate ventilation in the back because the hall way to the bathroom and the bathroom itself feel like being in inside an oven.  

They actually have a computer register system.  But being  high tech doesn't make up for taste.
author: e g.

description: When I was looking for a place to live, one of my criteria was that there had to be a pho restaurant within reasonable walking distance. Pho Vietnam helped me make that call for my current pad. Good, solid, pho. Not exceptional, but it hits the spot when you're craving a bowl of Pho Dac Biet with extra cilantro on the side, especially after a night of heavy drinking. The flavor of the broth tends to range from time to time- sometimes it's savory and packed full of flavor, other times it tends to be a little watered down. It's the folks that work here that keeps me coming back- they're friendly, quick, and appreciates their regulars. I have a crush on the grandmother (I call her Ma Vietnam) that works here, she is the most energized and feisty woman over 60 I've ever come across! Always hustling with a harassed expression on her face, she definitely keeps the show running. Thanks Ma Vietnam for all of the care you put into my pho!
author: Alice P.

description: pho is the best hangover cure (along with a few bottles of vitamin water), and this place is not too far from my apartment...perfecto!  i went here a few weekends ago with a group of my loudest friends, and the staff was patient and polite to us even though i'm sure we were by far the most annoying people in there.  i shared the appetizer sampler with a gf and ordered a regular steak pho.  delicious and satisfying...and not too much msg.  can't ask for much more...except for a pho place to open RIGHT next to my house.
author: Michelle W.

description:
Cruising on Polk with the intention of going to Nick's Tacos.  We passed by a well-lighted Pho joint that I haven't seen before.  We're always looking for a good Pho place in the City.  Since we're both hungry and thought that Pho will be quick, we decided to stop.  

Looking into the restaurant, we were encouraged by the number of occupied tables at around 7PM.  We ordered, the Goi Cuon (Spring rolls) for 2 and a bowl of Pho Tai (rare beef) and an order of Bun Cha Hanoi.  The food took a lot longer than we anticipated.  The Goi Cuon was adequate, but the bean sprouts were brownish, probably sat around for too long. I took out the sprouts and ate it anyway, hate to waste food.  Then came my bowl of Pho Tai, the broth was a little sweet and a bit heavy on the star anise for my taste, I would rate it a 2 out of 5, not a total disaster, but I wouldn't go back here for Pho.  Next is the Bun Cha Hanoi, which is a northern specialty - grilled pork with vermicelli dish, if done the right, this dish is heaven.  However, Pho Vietnam butchered this dish in a way that I've never seen or tasted before, anywhere.  The broth of fish sauce was way too salty, the meat was pinkish (unrecoqnizable), they put some kind of cabbage in the broth that's too weird to describe.  We tried 2 pieces of meat and left the rest alone.  The older waitress came by and asked why we didn't eat, my better half flashes her a smile, then she asked if we wanted to take it home, again another smile, the waitress looked puzzled, but took our plates away.  We paid our bill and left the Pho Vietnam for our intended destination, Nick's Tacos where we should have been in the first place.
author: Kevin T.

description: Read the reviews, but still opted for it since it's so close to my house.  The food was ok - blander than other pho I've tasted.  Next time I'll opt for the cab ride to get some better pho.
author: Leslie R.

description: Wow, I was very pleasantly surprised by this place.  I got the pho with beefballs and the steak on the side.  Delicious broth and vegetables.  It went down in a hurry, and since I only live a couple blocks away, I'm sure I'll be back many times.
author: Luke P.

description: not bad.  i've had worse pho in my life.  they only offer one size, and it is a bit more expensive than places in san diego.  sure, i'd go back... but i wouldn't mind trying a different one next time.
author: Sean L.

description: yay, finally a decent pho place in my hood!
author: Larissa D.

description: my neighborhood  pho place, the cheaper alternative to out the door when i want to be on a budget.  not half bad.  can't go wrong with pho on a cold night, and the grilled pork/rice dish is good too.  the restaurant is not pretty, it looks like a big cafeteria.  i wish they did vietnamese sandwiches.  but, food is a good price for what you get.
author: yolanda f.

description: Really 2.5 stars.  I've gotten the bun with shrimp here a number of times when in a pinch and every time I leave thinking I'm not coming back.  The noodles always seem a little too sticky, and the whole dish is a little too greasy and sweet.  Also not a fan of the fried onions they top it with.  On the positive side, the servings are huge.  And it's not horrible by any means but I think everywhere else I've been is better.
author: Mel X.

description:
Pho Vietnam serves authentic, delicious, cheap Vietnamese food.

I go to Pho Vietnam not for their pho, which I've only tried once and would give 3.5.  The broth and noodles were good, but I wasn't too sure about the beef in the pho tai.  Perhaps I'll try it again when I have a hankering for pho.

Instead, I've tried several other dishes (generous portions) that are delicious and upon which I base the 5-star rating.
#6 chicken salad (goi ga):  Fresh veggies (mainly uncooked cabbage, not lettuce) with fried shallots, ground peanuts, and boiled chicken.  Add some red chili to the fish sauce (nuoc mam) and then pour that over the salad.
#29 spicy noodle soup (bun bo hue): Thicker rice noodles, beef (I think brisket), and tendon in a spicy broth.
#17 wonton noodle soup (mi hoanh thanh):  You get at least half a dozen wontons filled with pork.  In addition, the broth contains thin slices of pork and ground pork.
#31 grilled shrimp over vermicelli (bun tom nuong):  Pretty generous # of shrimp over cold, thin rice vermicelli noodles.  Don't forget to pour the fish sauce (nuoc mam) over the shrimp and noodles.
#32 pork shish-ke-bab with rice (com thit nuong):  The pork isn't really in the form of a shish-ke-bab, but that's not the point.  It is very well-seasoned in the manner that "thit nuong" should be.  If you feel so inclined, try ordering the fried egg with this or any other of the rice dishes that feature pork.

I also like that soft drinks are served from a fountain rather than from a can, and you get a large glass.

The restaurant isn't located with most of the other Vietnamese restaurants in the heart of the Tenderloin, so I don't feel uneasy eating here at all.  Service is fast and friendly.  The decor is not anything to remark about except that it's very clean.
author: N C.

description: finally, n and i have a place to go for a bowl of late-dinner pho when we don't feel like trekking over to the sunset! why did it so long for us to find you?? bowl of pho was decent, although paying $1.75 for adding 2 meatballs? seriously? guess i'll just stick to the steak and tendon next time. spicy pork noodle also quite nice - broth surprisingly light and refreshing but still spicy. fresh spring rolls not as herby as i like them and as i've been taught to make them though.
author: Angi C.

description: back when i was a pho-n00b, i thought this was the spot. having been to a few joints down in san-ho and having been to tu lan over by the warfield, though, i'm singing a different tune. this is the kind of 3-star rating that shouldn't deter you altogether...pho vietnam slops together a decent pot o' broth that will leave you sated [not ill, like the 1-star jobs out there] without feeling like the dingy cafeterias where i'm accustomed to supping on bowl after slurptastic bowl. give it a shot if you're close by and thirsty.
author: Jon W.

description: Probably one of the best places in SF for a good bowl of hot pho!  My hubby and I eat here at least once a week.  They give you a healthy amount of noodles & beef... and the broth is amazing!  Another regular dish I get is the 5 spice chicken with vermicelli and the imperial rolls.  Less a star because we have to find street parking and they don't deliver.
author: Mochi L.

description: terrible..instant pho broth and old veg are not good ingredients. 4 slices of meat blows ass too. the old lady was as freindly as a rectal exam to boot.
author: santiago c.
